attributes.GoodForMeal: {'dessert': True, 'latenight': None, 'lunch': True, 'dinner': True, 'brunch': None, 'breakfast': False}

text:
Crawfish Benedict - yummy!!!

Royal House was the perfect start to my first trip NOLA! After going for a quick jog in the morning, I was hungry and ready to enjoy some delicious New Orleans food. 

There was no wait on a Saturday morning - unlike Petunias down the street (which is totally not worth the wait...I'll explain in my review later). The host was super friendly. The food arrived quickly. It was decently priced (approx. $11). And, the food tasted awesome! I'm a benedict lover, and this crawfish benedict was one of the best benedicts I've had! It was served with this creamy shrimp sauce - not hollandaise. This was a nice, unique touch. The crawfish was fresh - obviously! The side of cajun potatoes were also delish. 

I highly recommend this place before it becomes crazy touristy ;-)

We stopped in Royal House for a late afternoon lunch because Domino the host pulled us in with a promise that they could create a vegetarian meal. With him and Scott as our server, this was some of our best service in the city. It's a casual place with a focus on oysters. We ordered the spinach artichoke dip, which was DELICIOUS. They specially prepared a vegetarian muffaletta for my friend and i had the crab platter. Definitely recommended for the service and decent food. Nice ambience with the ceiling fans and open windows in the French Quarter. 

Also - we were sent here from Brennan's, which had just stopped serving lunch

Royal House is a good place to stop in and have breakfast if your not in the mood to stand in line for hours elsewhere. They serve up the usual breakfast fare with a creole/cajun twist with the emphasis on creatures that lurk in the deeps.

A quick word of warning for those a little adverse to seafood: The eggs benedict are served with a crawfish/seafood hollandaise sauce which isn't explained on the menu so if your not a big seafood fan it might be best to get the sauce served on the side.

I have attempted to replicate their charbroiled oysters and have come nowhere close.  "Plump Louisiana oysters, fresh shucked and topped with a zesty lemon and Parmesan cheese filling then broiled to bubbly perfection."  Not to sound like a fatty, but I was scrapping the cheese off the shell with my knife (okay, I lied... my nails!  I didn't want to sound like a super fatty).  My tour guide loves oysters and has tried many charbroiled oysters around NOLA and says Royal House is definitely the best.  

Furthermore, since it was my first NOLA meal, my tour guide suggested I get the Taste of New Orleans, which allows you to sample the city's dishes: chicken and sausage jambalaya, crawfish etouffee, and chicken and sausage gumbo.  My personal favorite of the three was the etouffee, but that was my first time having it, so I don't have anything to compare it to.

AND I don't remember what the drink was called, but I had this mango drink from the bar that our server recommended.  SOOOO GOOD!

It might not be as old as all the other places, but their recipes and service are perfected.  I miss you, Royal House!

Great People, Great Food!  What more can you ask for?

I stopped in this week to grab a late dinner.  I was in town for business so I grabbed a seat at the bar and started chatting it up with the guy working there.

I'm guessing he was 20 years old, and knew the menu well.  Made a few recommendations and we continued to talk.

I ordered the "trio" sampler that consisted of oysters done a few different ways.  One of the best dishes I've had in NOLA.  I've been to all the fancy places in NOLA and the food was in line with some of the places that will charge you 4 times more.  

The food was way above average... Friendly staff working there... I would go back again in a heart beat!  

Highly recommended!

I can't think of a restaurant in NO with higher standards for a very moderate price. Excellent Gumbo, Redfish, Salmon, Crab and Corn Soup, Spinach Salad, and the best Hurricane and Bloddy Mary in town. Friendly service from the door/maitre'd on into the restaurant. The oyster bar is just fantastic and so are the people serving the oysters. It was my favorite place in New Orleans. I will be recommending it.

I was wandering down Royal Street, looking for a place to stop and rest my weary feet, get a snack and hydrate.  Royal House had some nice window tables and I asked if I could have one to have a snack. (I always feel like I have to apologize for not ordering a full meal and taking up prime real estate....)

The host and waitstaff were great.   I had some of the best fries I have ever tasted (the tell me the secret is the fries are dipped lightly in batter first).

Great people watching and lovely fries, what more can a weary tourist ask for.

I believe Royal House is in the same Brennan family restaurant dynasty, cousin to the larger Bourbon Street location called, Bourbon House. Food and the scene here is much better (and a bit more civil and relaxed), as good as any oyster house in the French Quarter. The corner location offers a long bistro-like bar, friendly bartenders, and scattered tables for a proper sit down meal. It's hard to recommend any one dish over another - it's either raw, baked or fried - take your pick. Veggies, but for a couple salads, are missing from the menu.

So, on my trip to New Orleans, my coworker & I made it a point to wrap up our work on our last afternoon there, to carve out some time for Bourbon Street. We had made the walk down, scored some brewskies & were back out on the street (man, Atlanta's really gotta get an area like this) hunting for some dinner, 'cause the drinking wasn't going to get far, on empty stomachs. After checking out a few side streets from Bourbon, we came down to Royal, and saw the Royal House Oyster Bar; unlike a lot of the joints we had ambled past, this place neither had a line running down the street, nor was it deserted, which never bodes well for the food within. 

We were waved in by a friendly maître d' who welcomed both us and the milk-pail-sized beers in our mitts (again, just gotta love this town), and were taken right back to a table by the bar, with a window for people watching. My coworker went for the "Taste of New Orleans", which is a single plate featuring the 'holy trinity' of Louisiana cuisine, Jambalaya, Etoufee & Gumbo. All three looked pretty good, and came together to make up a pretty heavy-portioned plate of food. 

I figured, I'm in an oyster bar, heck, why not be different & go for the oysters? I love Oysters Rockefeller, and a half dozen of those got penciled in first, on my wish list. I completed my order with the Oysters Royale, & stuck with the tub of malted goodness I had brought in with me. The kitchen must have been pretty well stacked, staff-wise, because the food came out pretty quickly.

 I soon had two rock-salt-laden platters groaning under the weight of the most monstrously-mounded oyster-goodness concoctions I've ever seen. These things were piled high, folks. If you're the type who likes to get a dainty niblet of oyster with every mini-forkful of dressing, you're going to need really good knife skills. Otherwise, you're going to have to gnosh your way down to where the bivalve resides. The dressings were light & moist on the inside, a testament to delicate handling on the part of the cooks. They were baked off to delectable perfection.  The Oysters Royale struck me as a little bland, but that could perhaps be due to being enjoyed alongside the Oysters Rockefeller, which were packed with flavor. 

A side note on the Rockefellers here; they're a good deal spicier than I've had anywhere else before. I chalked that up to being in New Orleans, and still enjoyed them immensely, but if you're capsaicin-averse, you might want to consider some of the other offerings...or order a glass of milk. My dinner ended up consisting entirely of the dozen oysters, but even after handing over two for sampling purposes, I departed as stuffed as the oysters had been. Bravo, Royal House, may you enjoy a long run in the French Quarter, for I shall be back. Merci Bien.

A dozen fresh oysters on a platter $12.

Not getting sick (which means they were good quality) = priceless!

Bloody Mary and a side of Jambalaya were major pluses!

5 stars in my book just because of getting a dozen oysters at $12 is a major find!
Delicious huge po' boys and kicking Hurricaines.  Perfect lunch to start the party.

My husband told me to remember that I was married while I was in New Orleans.  I was offended by that comment until I walked by Royal Oyster House.  The host outside beckoned me over with hand gestures that I just couldn't ignore.  I took a long hard look at what he had to offer, licked my lips, and brought my hungry eyes to his.  He didn't even have to ask.  Yes was implied.  The platter of food he pointed to was tantalizing and I just couldn't say no.  My mind was made and I took my date's hand and sat down for a sinfully delicious dinner at Royal Oyster House, without even a thought about my husband.

My dinner date (my mom!) and I started off with the Chicken and Sausage Gumbo (delicious, very rich and creamy and probably made with lots lard).  For our entrees I ate the Chicken Marsala and my mom ate the Crawfish and Crabmeat ravioli.  Somehow we still managed to save room for dessert too.  My mom had the bread pudding (topped with white chocolate sauce) and I had the banana foster cheesecake.  I wish I had saved the calories for the banana foster french toast I ate the next morning...it was the only part of the meal I didn't drool over.

Overall, Royal House Oyster Bar is a cozy and casual restaurant that could be very romantic if you weren't there with your mom.  But If your date isn't satisfying, at least the food is.

NEW ORLEANS!!!!   We walked from the Hilton to the French Quarter... FUN!  we didn't know where to go, then we saw the Royal House, greeter outside, jazz on the streets.. we sat in the doorway.. listened to jazz... 

I had Grilled oysters, first for me, they where great (we went back once more, it was that good...)  just butter, salt, huge oysters!

and PIMM'S CUP!  they knew what it was (the bartender did, the server did not).. served with cucumber not with a orange, but still good..

great place, great food, great fun!

Had never heard of Royal House. We just stumbled in here for our first meal in the city. Our hotel was in the Quarter, it was late, and Bourbon street was pissing us off. 
Who knew that we'd have both the best Po' Boy and the best chargrilled oysters of our entire stay. 
Po' Boy on excellent bread loaded with perfect oysters where the oystery goodness was augmented not drowned by the crispy fry coating. 
Accompanied by the only grilled oysters we ever found in NOLA that came with just a hint of real, fresh grated (as in strands) cheese on top. Applied with restraint and respect. Every other green-can-parmesan abused oyster we had afterwards was just a sad reminder that the Royal House does it right. 
People were friendly, but the service was spotty. Don't argue about who is supposed to be helping us within earshot. Just take our order.

first night in NOLA and my GF and i wanted a drink off of bourbon st.  randomly ended up here. we were a bit hungry so we got some oysters... and then we learned after ordering that THIS PLACE MAKES A MEAN OYSTER!!

shit, were these good. I mean, really really good.   If you want a good oyster and are in the NOLA area, then then hit this spot.

The Bloody Mary here is really good, though not as well priced as Mr. B's.  The Oyster Rockefeller was very well done.  I ended up having three and I'm not even a huge oyster fan.  We split a burger which was plenty of food for us.  Best thing was sitting upstairs with sun shining into the room.

I have mixed feelings about this place.  On the one hand the food we ordered was pretty good- except the char grilled oysters which are 100 times better over at ACME.  However- we tried to order the seafood basket with lobster (also comes with mussels, clams and shrimp)- however they were out of lobster.  I suggested they substitute the snow crab, but the waiter tells me that would rip us off as lobster is way more expensive then snow crab.  He then says we should order the snow crab plate and get a pound of peel and eat shrimp.  We get the bill and the snow crab plate with peel and eat shrimp is over $10 more then if we had just substituted crab for the lobster in their peel and eat shrimp.  Could not help but feel we got screwed.  Also- dont get the royal sauce for your po boy- its like $5 for sauce and they dont tell you.  AND their drinks are weak and overpriced. $10 bloody mary of which maybe had 1 shot.  I went to some great places in New Orleans- ACME, Napoleon House, Verti Mart- and never felt so over priced.  But the food was good, so really it was dissatisfaction will kind of sketchy service.  Good food, but if you go be well aware of the bill.  and drink elsewhere.
Quick service with great raw and fried oysters.   Good value for you $

Recipe: Happiness in New Orleans

Ingredients:

2 seats on Royal House balcony
2 NYC residents, drunk to taste
1 musician on the street below, strumming guitar
2 Bloody Marys, slightly overpriced
12 buttery, garlicky, lemony, parmesany char-broiled oysters

Directions:

1. Combine ingredients in late afternoon, preferably sunny.
2. Add lack of responsibilities, if in season.
3. Serve with good conversation.

Enjoy.

My husband and I visited New Orleans over Easter Weekend from Los Angeles. We found Royal House to be a very french looking restaurant. It is close...but far enough away from the insanity Bourbon Street. We sat at a little table by an open french door. We had a half dozen Char-boiled oysters that tasted soooooo good. Also had a great, tasty crawfish salad. For desert we had a spectacular white bread putting. Everything was unbelievable. By the way, service was really good. The guy that was host, guided us to our seat . He was very funny and friendly. The waiter was very cool too. We will go back when we visit New Orleans.

Randomly stopped by here the day before the French Quarter Festival started.  I was in town for a deposition and needed a quick lunch.  The shrimp poboy was disappointing.  That's all I can really comment on.  The bartender was very helpful, but a little too chatty.  I'd go back and give it another chance but there are so many other places to try!  "bout all I got on this one.

I had dinner there on a Wednesday night. Is was pretty busy but not full.  I had the spinach salad, which was excellent, and the Taste of New Orleans entree--jumbalaya, gumbo, and etouffe.  I didn't like the etouffe, but it was seafood, which I don't care for. The flavor was very rich.  The jumbalaya and gumbo were very good.  The jumbalaya had a good range of flavor and the gumbo was rich and spicy.

The service was excellent.

Food: 3.5/5
Ambiance: 4/5
Services: 3.5/5
Prices: $$$ (above 20/person)

Thanks to Gini R for Yelping this on her recent visit to NOLA. I bookmarked it right away and brought my partner here for lunch on a beautiful Saturday afternoon. We were ushered up to the balcony to experience the wonderful sights and sounds of NOLA. The dining room upstairs has a great atmosphere with white table clothes, hardwood floors and open doors, reminiscence of the colonial-style "kopitiam" around south-east asia!

Being in the south and famous for their sweet tea, i asked the waiter if they have something like "Twisted Tea", he came back with a cocktail called "Firefly" $6.50, I think its vodka with sweetened grapefruit tea, definitely refreshing even though i am not a big fan of spirit! We ordered the following:

Taste of New Orleans $15.95, I was suckered into ordering this as they described it as "The Holy Trinity, a sampling of cities best dishes, chicken & sausage jambalaya, crawfish etouffe & chicken & sausage gumbo", i sub the gumbo for seafood. Basically, each dishes in cup with 3 thin slices of baguette. The jambalaya was the best, both the etouffe & gumba were a bit runny, still tasty but not WOW!

Royal Spinach Salad $10.95 add $4.95 grilled shrimp + $4.95 blackened scallop ($20.85). Baby spinach, sliced red apples, blue cheese, craisins & candied pecans with balsamic vinaigrette, now this is WOW! A perfect lunch dish that is very refreshing especially in summer time temp. Of course you can skip the additional but we both love our seafood...

I know there's plenty of restaurants in this beautiful city that has similar ambiance and setting but Royal House started our day wonderfully before venturing further into the French Quarter. My partner was surprise to see NOLA in the daytime and loving it compare to the bustling and mostly obnoxious night crowds!

Good Bloody Mary's.  Very similar to the Bloody Mary at "Corner" but no Okra and nothing on the rim of the glass.  These cost more too - 10 dollars.  Served in a cheap plastic cup made to look like a real glass.  I saw them make one.  They have a dispenser that sets at the bar with an olive infused liquid they put directly into the drink.  I didn't get a pic but they granted me permission to use a photo from their website.  It's on the left of the oyster pic-- looks like a water cooler with olives in it.

They charbroiled oysters were very good.  Perhaps better than the Crazy Lobster's.  These were simple with  butter, Parmesan and sea salt.  Went well with the Bloody Mary.  

I should have gotten a real meal but fried food is my one true love. It didn't disappoint but I found myself longing for something green... like the one the seafood salads.  Husband got a nice meal and he commented more than once how much he enjoyed his pan seared salmon and veggie dish.  

The waiter was helpful and friendly.  He brought me water to go with my drink without me having to request it (actually less common than you would think).  The seating was comfortable and well spaced.  Didn't feel too crowded, even though there were a lot of people there. 

Spent more than I expected the meal to be but I dropped 20 bucks on Bloody Marys alone.  Aww well, I feel it was worth it.

This is the first place we stopped at on our recent visit to NOLA. We just walked by and decided to have a snack and an adult beverage, 

We sat at the bar and ordered a couple of appetizers the Crab Claws and some Charbroiled Oysters. Both were heavenly but it was the crab claws that made us go back before we returned home. On both trips we soaked up the sauce int he bread while searching for more morsels of crab. If your worried about your diet I wouldn't suggest them (actually I would they are cheat on your diet good). 

The service was attentive, portions are average and the prices are reasonable for NOLA.. It was a warm sunny afternoon I wish we knew about the balcony seating the other reviews mentioned it would have been even better,

we ate here this past weekend and had a good time.  ate at the bar, and the service was good.  the gentleman that waited on us was hilarious and told us lots of funny stories.  

we had peel and eat shrimp and the "taste of new orleans" and were very happy with both.  it's right off of bourbon street, but a little quieter than that.  our friends ended up going there the next night for dinner and they really liked it too.  i would definitely go back the next time i am in town.

I randomly strolled in the Royal House one Saturday afternoon and sat right at the oyster bar. The staff was super nice and we enjoyed visiting with them and the other diners at the bar. I ordered a dozen oysters and split the Hot N' Blue Oyster po-boy and it was FABULOUS!!! I compared all other meals to this one the rest of the weekend.

It's day three and had so many oysters but could not resist this place.

The catfish platter and j-laya will knock your socks off and send you home with a dirty checkbook. If you like oysters rockefeller, this is the place- Although not as good as ACME.

Great place friendly service!!!

We walked over and the guy at the door gave us the normal "come on in speech", not knowing that we planned to stop at Royal House. He sat us down and we started a multi-course affair.

Oysters, stuffed with gooey fatty stuff, baked. Trio of seafood gumbos, muffaletta, desert. 

I'd go back in a heartbeat, next time we go to NOLA, for sure.

This restaurant looked great passing by, nice decor, atmosphere, but the food, drink and service was terrible.  I sat at the bar, and the mint julep I ordered, just tasted bad.  The side salad came with wilted leaves, with lots of rotten edges to the greens.  The oyster app. was just OK.  The bar tender could have cared less about my existence.  As I waited for my dinner, an unhappy couple down the bar from me was told the restaurant was out of a dish he had ordered a LONG while earlier, and they were pretty frustrated.  
Then the dish I had ordered, ten minutes later after ordering, I was told was sold out.  The bartender said she'd give me a free drink on the house.  So I point to a bottle of red wine against the wall behind her.  She pours the remains in to the glass, and while trying to block my view, grabs another bottle of red wine to finish filling up the glass.  I sat there and drank a glass of mixed wine and wondered how many other bartenders and waitresses/waiters pull this trick off.
The dinner alas came -not exactly what I ordered, with overcooked vegetables, almost grey in appearance with cracks in the carrots (?).  The fried seafood which quickly got cold, only allowed me to taste the thick fried breading -not the fish.  
And when I left, the manager followed me out, gave me his business card apologizing for being out of the dish I wanted.  
It's obvious a lot of tourists go here, sadly.

Last night in NOLA and wanted to try a new place.  Nice place on the corner not too crowded, seemingly clean.  Our host was extremely courteous and wiped of our table that was already clean but not to his standards...very nice!  Anyways, our waiter Shane was nice, well spoken, and knew the menu well.  

The menu was a bit limited but too many choices is taxing as well.  The prices were higher than ACME but not unreasonable.  Started off with oysters and were pleased but pricey i thought $14 for a dozen.  We ordered the Taste of New Orleans and the Salmon Bercy.  The gumbo was tasty but the etouffee and jambalya were just okay.  The salmon (big piece) on the other hand was very delicious with a garlic lemon sauce with crab meat...mmmm, that was the shiznit!

Only had appetizers at Royal House and they were GOOD.

Sauteed crab legs were hot and flavorful. The bread accompanying the crab legs was awesome and great to dip in the sauce. We had to request more bread to enjoy all the sauce. The crab legs were broken into small pieces so they were easily editable without great deal of work.

Charbroiled oysters were good but can't compete with Acme. They were hot and flavorful but no seasoning to add flavor or otherwise.

Clams and mussels were a problem initially. They came out room temperature warm. Not sure if they didn't want to make them so hot because the shells were warm but the content was luke warm at best. We sent them back and the waitress fixed it within minutes.

Service was awesome. Waitress kept our glasses full the entire time. Met each of our request regarding our food, getting more bread, and finally she offered to bring us to-go water to survive the summer heat and humidity.

BEST BLOODY MARY IN ALL OF NEW ORLEANS!!!  Hands down.
Their Charbroiled Oysters are pretty fantastic as well... cooked to perfection every time. 

Great location makes it easy to stop in for a snack or drink whether it be morning, noon, or night.  Love this place!!

My friend's and I stopped in here for drinks around 10:30 on a Thursday night.  The place was empty except for a few tables and were seated by a very quiet waiter. My friend said "Hi!" and the waiter replied "Not yet...later though!"   So after we finished laughing about that, we ordered a Mojito, a Big Boy Root Beer Float and some alcoholic, coconut drink.  The mojito was surprisingly sub-par for how simple it is.  It was not stirred at all and the proportion of rum to soda was disgusting.  The root beer float was an interesting concept with rum, amaretto, root beer and ice cream.  This was good, but I felt that if I finished it all I would have been a hot mess on Bourbon Street.  Thank god for sharing.  The coconut drink was refreshing, but nothing special.  I realize this review is based solely on drinks, and I have heard that the oysters here are good.  This review doesn't cut Royal House out from my dining possibilities, but I wouldn't order specialty drinks here again.

I came in here for a cup of coffee after seeing the insane line at Cafe Du Monde.  A lady walked in and ordered a bloody mary that looked great so I switched.  Probably one of the best decisions I made while in New Orleans.  It was one of the best Bloody Mary I've ever had.  I sat there drinking bloody marys and had to partake in an order of raw oysters.  They were fresh and delicious.  What made the whole meal great was the great convo by my bartender Bradley.  He gave me great advice about what to see in New Orleans, and provided great service.  I will be back to the Royal House on my next trip to New Orleans.

Was looking for oysters my first night in the French Quarter and was drawn in by the neon "Oyster Bar" sign above the bar.

This is an upscale place with a lot of charm and great service.    Started with  a dozen oysters and then had the seafood steamer pot with lobster, clams and shrimp which was excellent.   

Had a great time.

What a fantastic Experience!! It was our 1st trip to New Orleans and we really wanted to try something unique to New Orleans. We discovered this place with the help of Yelp and it was quite a find!  The New Orleans sampler was incredible and served with a Cesar salad. The 5 layer Chocolate was a true experience, the BEST I have ever had!

I was walking with my group from Bourbon Street to Jackson Square and we decided to stop here for lunch. Quite a treat!

We started with some oysters, and were presented with a dozen of the best that we had while in New Orleans. Plump, flavorful, awesome. My boyfriend and I got the crawfish etouffee, my sister ordered the muffaletta, and her husband got the redfish. I quite enjoyed the sauce in my etouffee but thought they could have been a bit more generous with the crawfish. My boyfriend was more bothered by the latter fact, but I guess I'll take what I can get. My sister loved her sandwich, which was large enough that we were all able to have a fry or two. The fries that came with it were fresh and crisp. My brother-in-law said he quite approved of his redfish. 

Service was quite good, and the prices were not horrible for what you get. Definitely a nice lunch spot.

I have to say we didn't experience alot of the Royal House, but what we had we loved.  

Stopped here for a quick bloody mary around lunch on a Sunday.  We were looking for a place for bloody mary's with a balcony overlooking the action down below, this place did both perfectly and that's all we could ask for.  

The younger gentleman greeting outside was actually pretty hilarious.  We were dressed as doctors for Halloween and his opening line was something like, "You doctors want some greasy unhealthy food to start your morning?", pretty hilarious, of course, we wanted alchohol instead, but it got us in the door, know your clientele I guess.  

A quick trip up the stairs gave us a couple choices of seats on the outdoor balcony with just a great view over the streets below.  Our server upstairs was quick and efficient, even if we didnt order a ton of stuff.  $10 bloody marys are pretty standard in this town and I have no complaints at all.  

Obviously can't comment on the food but I would go back here in a second for drinks on the balcony again.  We also noticed that so many places have balconies but most seem to rent them only to private parties or they simply are not open for the public most of the time.  This exception here was really nice to find.

with a restaurant.com gift certificate in hand, my husband and i went for the big one. the expensive boiled pot that comes with a lobster and crab legs. 

unfortunately, we made a bad decision as our pot was smaller than what we anticipated for $60. the lobster and crab legs were ok. the oysters and clams were chewy and there was a piece of corn on the cob. if it weren't for the three potatoes, i would have been starving. 

there's other options out there we should have tried.

Great food! Stopped here after the restaurant I was looking for was closed, but this place was very nice and the food was outstanding. Oysters were good, drinks were ok, but the entrees were wonderful. 

Blackened redfish, salmon with crab and butter sauce, I wanted to lick my plate. 

Servers were very nice and happy to share their opinions and recommendations. Little pricey, but not too bad, especially for the excellent quality!

At least the salad wasn't iceburg but it was still good.

Three words: Flur De Tini. Yes please!! So yum!

Gumbo, you rocked my world. You gave my spicy tummy a run for it's money. 

Bartender was cool. I love NOLA because football is on even in the nicer resturants like this one was.
Love the gumbo - one of the best in the city. Great ambiance on the corner of Royal.

Food:  Pre-shucked oysters sitting in melting ice served to us- on two visits.  

Ambience:  ok

Service:  ok

The food is average to above average, the service is not so great, at least when seated at a table.  The service at the bar is quite a bit better.  The food is okay but in this price range there are numerous other restaurants in Nola that I would suggest...

I'd give it a 3.5 if possible...

1. Great drinks menu. Fleur de tini does the trick.
2. Great service with a very accomodating staff.
3. TOO MUCH SALT. I thought after my oyster pasta that I was going to have a heart attack. I've never had that much salt in one plate in my life. It was a huge turnoff for me and the reason why this place gets 2 stars instead of the 3 or 4 it should have gotten with the nice atmosphere, service, and drinks.

This was where we had dinner on Saturday night while I was in NOLA.  The place didn't have a line compared to other restaurants in the french quarter, not sure if that's a good / bad but we got seated immediately upstairs with a nice view out the open windows.

Had some gumbo that was great, dad enjoyed a plate of fried goodness, and stepmom had shrimp etouffee that she enjoyed.  I saved room for dessert which was a good decision - BANANAS FOSTER CHEESECAKE!! It was even better than it sounds.  Washed it down with an Irish coffee with Baileys. A perfect ending to a beautiful night.

hey so the service is nice,  but the food ...not so well. Im end up almost go to the emergency room because I ate one bad oyster here. I knew it was bad and throw up but i guess too late. I still can feel the stinky smell in my mouth. I told the manager about the death stinky oyster and she thought i complain because i wanted more oyster, look at me real mean and say" So what happened again?" B$%^, what happened is your restaurant use bad oyster, bad food and use u to be a manager. I refused more oyster she offered for me. Horrible experience.

Nothing Special.I am one of those annoying people who pick off the plates of the people around me so i sampled a lot.My ravioli dish was the best it declined in tasty after 3 bites but still good.The other things i sampled were sub par.I wouldn't visit again.Try "Oliviers".

I don't normally give five stars for a first visit but considering I can't stop thinking about the sauteed crab claws, it is worthy of five stars. Holy crap, seriously Royal House? The sauteed crab claws came with about 10 crab claws in a rich, creamy broth with four pieces of French bread to dip into the sauce. Delicious, delicious. My husband and I split this app yesterday but he is crazy if he thinks he is going to share it when we go back. And we WILL go back for that app today. I also had a cup of gumbo that was very good and a little spicy. In addition, to satisfy my crawfish fix, I ordered the crawfish cakes. Wow. I was a little worried since I am not generally into crabcakes, but these were so good. The crawfish cakes were also topped with chunks of crawfish and a creamy crawfish sauce over a bed of spinach. All that crawfish fit the bill perfectly for me. 

The table behind us ordered poboys and they looked huge! It seemed like you got your money's worth with those. Given we only have another day left in Nawlins, I won't waste my time with the poboys although they looked very good. My heart belongs with those sauteed crab claws.

so we wandered into the joint looking for some good cajun food and man did we hit the jackpot. We ended up going back a second time. The first time, we went for the sauteed crab claws. They came in a creamy garlic sauce. They were so good that wifey MADE me go back the next day for lunch. The 2nd go round, I decided to get me a po boy. I did half alligator and half shrimp. This po boy was the size of a small child, and yes I ate the whole thing. The gator was super tender and seasoned perfect. The shrimp were perfect as well, the batter was some of the best I've ever had. The bread...oh the bread....holy cow. I wish I could have that bread every day of my life. What a great little spot with awesome service.

We stumbled in here (staying across the street at the Royal Orleans) and where very plesantly surprised. great food and really friendly service. very good bar too, but the upstairs is very nice for families.

Only had the oysters on a half shell, but they were great! And cheap! And I've never been much of a raw oyster guy. The oyster bar guy was also our bartender. He was attentive and helpful. Had a great Amita on tap. Really good atmosphere, too. This was one of my favorite stops in NOLA.

We went into the Royal House to have a beer and get a snack for my friends.  The downstairs bar was cool - and packed full of people watching football.  The upstairs had the look of an old house with dark woods, a really cool looking bar, and quiet tables for dining.  

Our waiter came over and got us some drinks started immediately.  I liked his quick smile, his easygoing attitude, and his quick service.  They have a pretty good list of specialty drinks that pack a good punch while tasting better than they should.  The food menu looked great but I didn't set a chance to sample any of it.  However, the friends with me loved what they got so I guess that counts for something.  Also, the waiter didn't mind at all for us to sit up there and chat and drink more without ordering any more food.  Next time I come back I'll give it the chance it deserves and eat an entire meal here!
Best restaurant ever!!  Fried shrimp were to die for. And the fries were delicious!!!  Highly recommend to anyone.

Oh noz it's Saturday, it's starting to get dark, I'm hungry and on Bourbon Street! How did I end up in this predicament? I did my research before this trip and none of the eateries I bookmarked were in the quarter. I needed to get off Bourbon street quickly before the obnoxious drunken zombie tourists got me! I also didn't want to succumb to desperation and jump into any sub par restaurant/tourist trap. Thank goodness for my iPhone and the Yelp app which directed me one block over on Royal Street to the Royal House Oyster bar. We were seated quickly and had our orders taken in no time. I knew I was safe from douchebaggary when our waiter started quoting Bob Dylan and, subsequently, the three of us got into a lengthy discussion about our favorite Dylan albums. I had a mighty good shrimp po-boy and my boyfriend had a trio plate consisting of small portions of gumbo, jambalaya, and ettoufee. We started off with some delicious amazing craw-cakes covered with little shrimp and crawfish sauce. It all sounds very touristy-typical but the quality of food was there, plus the pricing was very reasonably spot-on. On top of all that, the bartender ain't no joke and whips up some great cocktails. Should you find yourself in the same situation as me, just walk one block over and trust in this place. We keep talking about how good the food was and will surely return on future visits to New Orleans.

Not going to lie.  Royal House is my hangover headquarters when I visit NOLA every Halloween.  (and not just because it's a stumble from the Omni Royal)

My NOLA hangover cure?  1-dozen oysters, French Onion soup and a Bloody Mary.  Try it.  I dare you =)

Love sitting in the openness whether it be on the main floor by a window watching the party people stumble by, or the quite upstairs with the breeze flowing through the windows.  Like most place in New Orleans, it's casual and comfortable.

See you Halloween 2011!

I'm at this place right now and its been 30 minutes since I've seen my server. Our wine glasses are empty and there is no food on our table. The oysters on the half shell were flavorless and served not cold enough in a plastic bin - very unattractive presentation. Oysters Rockefeller tasted microwaved. They are playing the radio, which is blaring Burger King commercials for optimum awful ambiance. Jesus, I wish my server would come so I could get the bill and go somewhere good.

Tired oysters for the 1st time here... I think the char boiled kind. I must say they weren't that bad and fresh. I can't speak for the rest of the food, all I had were the oysters. It was nice we sat by the french doors and people watched. The restaurant itself seemed kind of small.

After reading positive reviews about this place, I headed there through the inebriated post-Mardi Gras parade masses and litter-filled streets in the French Quarter, armed with a restaurant.com certificate and looking forward to dinner. Little did I know that it would turn into a dining experience that should have been included in one of Dante's rings of hell.

It was very busy so I was seated at the oyster bar at about 7:45 p.m. 20 minutes go by and people all around me (including customers who arrive considerably after me) are getting drinks and food and I don't even get a menu. I flag down one of the people who look like they're in charge to tell them I have not been helped and have not even gotten a menu; he apologizes and tells me that my dinner will be comped.

Meanwhile at the bar, Kenny, who's apparently the head shucker and the only shucker authorized to take dining orders, finally takes my order. I order what I would have with the certificate anyway: a cup of seafood gumbo and the crawfish platter. He repeats it thrice to make sure he has it right and I confirm it three times. I get the gumbo in about 10 minutes and it was pretty good with sausage, crawfish, and crab that had simmered down to small threads, then nothing. 

I am there for another hour and fifteen minutes before getting the crawfish platter. Kenny doesn't realize this even though he's the one who supposed to have put in the order. He has a shucker go out for a break, never to return. I had to ask 5 times about the platter and never got a straight answer. At 15-minute intervals, I kept being told by waitresses that "it will be right out in 5 minutes." As the interminable wait for the entree continued. I order a beer. I was nursing the beer and finished most of two beers before the crawfish platter finally arrived with crawfish cakes, fried crawfish, and crawfish etoufee.

I was so hungry and angry that the entree tasted like cardboard to me. Apologies and lack of responsibility by the staff don't make up for that 3 hour dining disaster in my life I'll never get back. Blaming the entree tardiness on the shucker who walked out is unprofessional and wrong. It may have contributed to this but was not the cause of the problem. This is not a leisurely hours-long dining kind of place. When a business can't get it right, they should make it right and not screw it up worse by not fixing the problem and lying and making excuses on top of it. The only good part of the meal experience was the bread pudding. Afterwards, Kenny had the cajones to say that he hoped I would return to Royal House. And re-live a horrible memory? Hell no!

I wanted to like you Royal House, I really did. 

We had an almost identical experience to a previous reviewer. We left the parade, party of nine, and made our way down here with a Restaurant.com certificate. 

Took us ages to be seated; we watched one of the "head shuckers" take a beer order for a couple of guys and serve them, but largely ignored us. When we tried to place an order for a drink, he sent us to the other end of the bar putting us squarely in the way of every waiter and waitress trying to get by with a tray. Nice. 

When we were finally seated, the service was painfully slow. Everyone at the table got their meal except for me; like 20 minutes of waiting without a plate. It was just as well, since everyone who was picking at their food said it was freezing like it was sitting on the counter forever. Gummy cold fries, etc. 

When my meal finally came out, it was a shrimp po boy (not the oyster one I ordered) but I was too starving to care. I plowed through it even though the shrimp was cold and had obviously been out of the fryer for a while. 

Our waitress was missing for very long intervals so it was nearly impossible to place a drink order. It looked like they had her working two sections and the other one was down a long flight of stairs, so I don't blame her for their inability to properly staff the restaurant and cook food for a large party while still keeping it hot. We ordered *sandwiches* for pete's sake. Even if you're slammed, you should be able to bring out sandwiches and hot fries in under 2 hours. 

Not only was nothing comped, (and I NEVER ask for that sort of thing, but somewhat expect a place to extend an olive branch if the service or food was an embarrassment)  we were considerably OVERcharged and had to send the bill back to be corrected. 

An all around disappointment. 

The manager stopped by and everyone mentioned the cold fries so he brought out some plates of hot ones, but this was one of the least satisfying meals we had in New Orleans.
Service sucked but the oyster were great and the bloody mary's were delicious! Don't bother with the salads they were overdressed and overpriced.

We stopped by for lunch on our last day in NOLA. It was a Monday afternoon, so it was pretty quiet. Service was fast and friendly. I had a Muffuletta and the husband got a 'Hot and Blue' po'boy. OH YUM. My sandwich was fantastic, but the big winner was the po'boy. Fried oysters with a Tabasco mayo sauce and blue cheese crumbles - heaven. French fries served with the sandwiches were perfect and crisp. Great food in a casual, comfortable atmosphere.

We were walking by an decided to give it a try. WOW the crabclaw app. was awesome!!!!! We also had oysters, yummie. Desserts looked yummie too but we didnt have a room left. Will have to go back and try those.

Most likely the best dinner we had during our stay in New Orleans.  The char grilled oysters are amazing...still craving them!  Our handsome waiter suggested fantastic items from the menu and everything was delicious!  He was awesome and even told us about some local hot spots to check out during our stay.  Do not miss this great romantic place!

Whenever we go to New Orleans, we usually get one thing and split it, because we eat about 12 times a day... we want maximum variety while not exploding. 

We stopped by Royal House on Lundi Gras, and were greeted with a limited menu - so they could turn and burn tables. No worries, though. We sat at the bar, and were greeted with really friendly service. We split a fried oyster platter - the Big Guy got the oysters and I got the hush puppies and we split the fries. Holy moly! Can hush puppies be made into an entire meal?! They are SO good! Fries are good, too. 

Food came out quickly, and service was great. We were in and out in no time. Prices aren't too out of hand, save the $10 bloody mary - seems like you get $10 worth of liquor, though... they're light on the mix.
Reliably slooooow service... but darn if they don't have the best Bloody Mary I've ever had in my life. (The oysters are good, too, but I'm not kidding about those Bloody Marys.)

Very tasty and the service was acceptable.  The salmon on the Salmon and Crabmeat Bercy plate was very good, veggies cooked just right but a little too much Cajun season salt on them.  The Banana's Foster Cheesecake was fabulous!  Overall a very good experience.

Stopped in for a light lunch and a bloody mary on the Saturday before Mardi Gras.  Well we ordered a plate of oysters each.  They were done on the grill with butter, garlic and parmesean cheese.  To die for!!!  we each ordered another plate, not because we were hungry, but they were just so damn good.  We also ended up back at this place the next night for dinner and more oysters.  

That night we had the best waiter who served us on the balcony.  He told us all about the costume contest on Bourbon Street on Fat Tuesday.  Well if he reads this, we did recognize you up on stage - BEAUTIFUL!!

GO!

We can here for dinner, around 6ish. It looked busy but there was no wait. Our hotel concierge recommended this restaurant so we also received a 15% discount :). We got a plate of the cooked oysters, Shrimp Creole, and the Taste of  New Orleans. I personally didn't like the crawfish etoufee in the Taste of New Orleans, but everything else was so delicious. We also got the bread pudding, which was fantastic. 

Service was a bit slow, which is why this is 4 stars. But overall this was a great restaurant. They open the side doors and at the time we were there, there were some street performers and we would enjoy during our dinner.

Beautiful day in NOLA - upper 70's and sunny with no humidity! We walked down Royal to grab lunch before leaving for the airport. The concierge at the Ritz recommended that we sit upstairs on the balcony at Royal House as it allowed us to watch people walking on the street - great suggestion!

One negative about that idea: being on the street means that drinks MUST be served in plastic cups, not optimal for drinking wine.  However, it stands to reason given the fact that it is New Orleans, with lots of alcohol flowing.

For starters, I ordered half dozen oysters and my husband ordered a cup of the seafood gumbo. Hmmmm  - his soup showed up and my oysters did not. When we asked, we were told that the waitress had to order the oysters from the bar (versus kitchen) and for some reason, she had asked them to delay delivery. I'm not sure why she thought that I wanted to wait to eat my oysters.

I then had the Taste of New Orleans, cups of Crawfish etoufee, jambalaya and chicken and sausage gumbo.  One word for them all - meh. I'm not an expert at New Orleans food but they were pretty bland and all seemed to taste somewhat the same. ...and then the oysters showed up. 

I've had dinner here many years ago and remember a very pleasant experience - I'll have to re-visit.

Had never had oysters on a half-shell, and thought we'd give it whirl. We ordered half a dozen charbroiled and the other half were raw, just to be on the safe side. Both were great...paired it with a glass of wine (not that great of a selection), but it was a great experience. The staff was very friendly, and attentive. I liked the atmosphere, people were chatting loudly, and everyone seemed happy with their experience as well. I'm surprised other yelpers had a bad experience, luckily that was not our case.
They ran out of raw oysters! Meh. Blame BP!! Bloody Mary rocks though. Definitely worth the stop if you are in Nawlins.
Went to brunch and had the bloody mary's, oysters, roasted oysters, and split a shrimp po boy.  Oh my my!

The Royal House was our final dinner outing in New Orleans and it was a great one.  Thank you, Peter D., for your review, which sort of sealed this one in for me.

We called around 7:15 to see if there was a wait.  The hostess said it'd be about 20 minutes, but asked for our name.  We gave her our info and said we'd be there within a half hour.

Half hour later, we showed up.  The hostess said it'd be about a 10 minute wait, which was fine by us.  We waited outside -- it was a beautiful night with low humidity and a light breeze.

Five minutes later the manager appeared to apologize for the long wait (what long wait?!) saying it'd be another 5 minutes.  He offered us complimentary drinks.  Don't mind if we do!  He took us to the bar, we ordered drinks and about a minute later, our table was ready.

We were shown to our table and greeted by our waitress who seemed to be in a frenzy.  She said she'd be right back, though right back was about 10 minutes later.  Thankfully we had our drinks already and weren't in any sort of rush.  She was very, very slow the rest of the night, but we were all taking our time eating and talking, so we didn't mind.  Normally this would have bothered me.

Onto the food...I tried the egglant appetizer -- I've actually never had eggplant and I have to say, I was not a fan, but my friends loved it.  For dinner, I got the Chicken Marsala, which was very good, but the sauce was a little thicker than I like.  The pasta was great and the chicken was plentiful and very juicy.  Normally I prefer chicken breast over cutlet, but it was still very good.  My friends all enjoyed their meals, as well.

The ambiance was wonderful.  We were seated inside, so unfortunately did not get to experience the balcony, but I really loved the atmosphere inside.  Had all the old charm of New Orleans with a bit of a modern feel.

If I ever go back to NOLA (and I hope I do!), I will be back.  The Blackened Chicken Sandwich was calling my name...

I had the charbroiled oysters and taste of new orleans. The oysters were melt in your mouth tasty good. The jambalaya had a weird powdery taste to it.. The etouille was good. The gumbo was good as well. And the abita beer was awesome as usual.
Best peel and eat shrimp, crab and corn bisque! Perfect lunch location, and well air conditioned!

Sometimes, simple things are just perfect.  That is the case with our visit to the Royal House.  When in New Orleans, you have to have oysters, right?   We had the Char-grilled Oysters and they were buttery, garlicy and delicious!  
Some Jack Daniels and a plate of these oysters were absolutely perfect and will stay in my memory for years!  Good Job Royal House!
A party of 30 was seated immediately before my party of two. Despite this, service was quick and very friendly! The charbroiled oysters were great, as was the blackened shrimp wrap!!!

If you're looking for a nice place with plenty of options off Bourbon Street, this place is it! It came recommended from our hotel, and it did not disappoint! We went for lunch. My muffuletta was great, and my husband's alligator po-boy was rocking. The prices are reasonable, and the food was great.

Not sure what the hype is about this place.. Bloody Mary is great because they use zing zang..  What isn't great with zing zang? Had the gumbo and it tasted like it was out of a campbell's soup can marinated in a shoe lost on the walk of shame out of the quarter early one morning.  Def over priced, but on a positive note the host was very outgoing and the wait staff was very friendly and attentive.
The food was excellent. Must try the Charbroiled Oysters and the Sautéed Crab Claws. Service was great too.

Taste of New Orleans was a good recommendation from my fellow yelpers.  The taste is a combo of all three goodness items from the big easy and all were good.  One cup was warm and not hot but wasn't bad.  The french bread was ok but expected better and more of it given the location.  Not a bad place but they could do better.  Might try again on another visit.  Service was friendly and setting/location was great.

We had tried going to a couple of oyster bars near Bourbon Street but at 7:00 in the evening, they both had long waits.  We discovered the Royal House and were able to be seated right away.  I had a oyster platter that offered Oysters Rockefeller and a couple of other types of baked oysters.  It was very good.  The bread pudding is made there, and mine was hot out of the oven.  The spouse had key lime pie and gave it a thumbs up.  The waitress was accommodating towards tweaking the menu for the picky eater in our party (who is 11).

We started with a dozen oysters on the half shell. Nothing too special there, which is the way you want it with raw seafood. The nexxt thing we ordered was the sauteed crab claws which were so delicious that I will be talking about them for the next few days. It came in a buttery sauce, served with a few pieces of toasted bread for sopping it up. The food was excellent, but I reccommend sitting at the bar, as I have had some bad service in the past.

Wow! Truly great! I wanted something that felt so new Orleans but wasn't going to make me feel to heavy or guilty by what i ate. I went with the red fish grilled and it could not have better. The veggies and steamed potatoes made the perfect side!

We came to Royal House twice while on our 4 day trip to New Orleans. The first time we sat at a table and got the Oyster Trio, Shrimp Po-Boy w/ chicken and Sausage Gumbo, and the Craw fish Po-boy with crab bisque. The Oyster trio was DELICIOUS We ended up only getting Oyster Rockefeller and some sort of seafood stuffed oyster. The Rockefeller was the highlight.. the other not so much. It was supposed to come with a third kind of Oyster.. but the said they were out of them.. which is weird since it's just oysters with a different seasoning on top.

Moving on.. the rest of the food except for the crab bisque was TERRIBLE. It took about 30 min to get our po boys. People who had walked in after us had to time to eat and leave before our food got to the table. When it did, it wasn't even hot. There is nothing worse than cold fried food, on hard french bread. Very disappointing.

The second time we came just for oysters and sat at the oyster bar. The service was very speedy, we got the char grilled oysters and the oyster Rockefeller. The char grilled didn't have any yummy crusty cheese or anything on top :( Just butter and seasoning.. so not that good. And the Rockefeller tasted completely different from the oysters we had the day before! Talk about inconsistent. I probably won't be back here when I return to Nola, but if you don't mind the inconsistencies I guess it could be a good place
Crab claw and the cooked oysters wow great stuff! Muffaletta was not good. Nawlins beer on tap is good

The sauteed crab claws were good enough to make the hair on the back of my arse rise!  The alligator and SoCo Mint Juleps will make ya kiss your Aunt Sass. Royal House. Bliss.

The staff (especially our waitress who was a Kentucky girl) were sweet as can be and so energetic and full of fun. We ate here 3 times during our trip and every single thing was worth the 6 hour trip. Have a drink, a gator, a claw...sit back, relax  and let the good times roll in true New Orleans fashion. Or get your julep to go and hit the streets. Royal House isnt too far from the french market and cafe dumond.
Great food at reasonable prices!  Had fun spur of moment lunch on girls road trip and would definitely go back.

We stumbled into Royal House for a late dinner when we got into New Orleans.  The bisques were yummy, and the Taste Of New Orleans plate was a great way to try all the classic favorites!  The service was friendly, although it was quite loud inside.
The best po-boy I had in New Orleans (bleu oyster & shrimp po-boy). Service was great and very friendly and a great atmosphere.

The services, atmosphere, and customer service was truly delightful. Additionally, the food and especially the drinks were above average and I would recommend anyone to experience this NOLA treasure!!!
Charbroiled Oysters, & Sautéed Crab Claws are soooooooo!!!  Awesome!!!  :-)'.

We came here for the first time because the line in front of Acme was ridiculous.  Glad we did - the oysters on the half shell were delicious and so fresh and the charbroiled oysters were phenomenal.  They're not cooked as long as those at Acme and the flavor is tremendous.  Glad to see that the cheese didn't overwhelm the oysters.  Jeffrey was incredibly busy shucking oysters and still made the time to make us feel welcome and provided friendly service.

We were staying near the French Quarter and decided to go for a stroll before getting dinner. We weren't sure what to expect walking in to Royal House but we were very pleasantly surprised.

I ordered the Baked Seafood Tortellini and it was AMAZING. I'm not sure why but I was honestly surprised with how good this dish was. The only mistake I made was that this was the first meal I had in NOLA and, while I ate some delicious food during my time there, it never compared to this Tortellini.

My girlfriend had the Crawi sh & Crabmeat Ravioli and, from all reports, she was almost as impressed with hers as I was with mine. 

We sat out on the balcony for our meal and, if you have the option, I would suggest sitting inside. It was nice to dine outside but there is a very noticeable lean to the balcony and it can be off putting.
Great place... the food was good and the service was great. One of my favorite dining experiences in NOLA.

Our server was excellent and courteous. The etouffe and the char-broiled and on the half shell oysters were all excellent. We did, however, see a bartender stick his hand into a jar of olives to pull some out, and another waiter was obviously and audibly upset about having to serve the international visitors seated at his table. He was also, quite rude to them. Good food - mixed service.

Got right on a weekday at about 6:30.  Service was fast and friendly.  The charbroiled oysters were excellent.  Both my date and I were skeptical of them, but they did not disappoint.  I had the shrimp creole which was good, but not great.  My date had the shrimp and scallop tortellini.  It was good, but very heavy.  She had a hard time finishing half of it, and it wasn't that big of a plate.  We shared a bananas foster cheesecake for desert, which was excellent.

If you want atmosphere and an unforgettable meal in NOLA, Royal House is the place!! 
This is our second time to eat here and it is now a tradition for our family! The crab claws are fabulous. Love everything on the menu. 
Ernest was our bartender, oyster shucker and waiter!! Best part of our dining experience was Ernest!

Total tourist trap. Should've followed my instincts. There are plenty of better places to eat, even in the quarter. The crowd ends up inevitably being annoying drunk tourists.  The food is BLAH.  The service is average.  Really, the only good thing off the menu was the charbroiled oysters, which were quite good.  But still, you're better off waiting at Acme or going to Felix for your touristy/oyster fix.

Thank you Peter D. This stop wouldn't have necessarily made it on our list except for his description of those buttery, garlicky, lemony, parmesany charbroiled oysters. On our Epic Jazz Hunt, we dropped into Royal House and ordered some wine and some snacks. Specifically the aforementioned oysters and the sauteed crab claws. 

Those charbroiled oysters almost caused a family feud. It was like hungry hungry hippo up in there, all of us grabbing and noshing and sopping and washing it down with a nice white. And that's all before we got to the crab claws. Those little lovelies were plump and tender, in a thick sautee that just begged to be mopped up my the fresh bread they were bringing out. 

After that feast of the gods, the eggplant sticks were disappointing. Not bad, just not "oh my god I'm going to murder someone for the last bite" good. And the muffaletta, which we saw brought out to another table, was literally the size of a bowling ball. This is a must do for everyone.

The food here is above average and the staff is really good. This is a typical joint for this part of town but it is at least off Bourbon Street, on Royal, so it's quieter and the crowd is a little more....upscale. The waiter really knew the menu well and made us some great recommendations. The redfish was excellent and their oysters were fresh-tasting and really good and good-sized. Their house bloody mary is pretty good if you like those sorts of things. 

It wasn't overly expensive in this area which tends to be a little bit higher-priced anyway. Overall, this wasn't a bad choice for a dinner.

Added one star automatically for only having to wait 5 minutes on New Year's Eve when Acme and Felix's both had people lined up outside. Maybe it was because we were only a party of two..

Anyhow, we ordered a half a dozen raw oysters and a half a dozen charbroiled. We also had the Hot N Blue Oyster PO Boy served with french fries (which we unfortunately could tell had come from a frozen bag). The building is really pretty and has tables upstairs on their wrap around balcony overlooking my favorite street in NOLA, Royal Street.
Can I get my oyster appetizers, oyster po-boys, and seat my party of eight within five minutes?  I can - wow.  Great food, cocktail selections, and service.  Recommend it!

It was Saturday, and my 49ers were playing the Saints in the 2nd round of the playoffs. I decided to save a beating and head to a calm bar off Bourbon Street, in which I could cheer on the hometown rivals without catching a bottle the skull.

I had been here earlier in the day watching street performers from the 2nd story balcony. I had the woodchuck beer, which was a cider- tasty. I had a cup of both the gumbos- the shrimp and the chicken&sausage. So good. 

2nd time around, I had the Shrimp Creole. WOW. This was my second attempt at this dish in NOLA, the first time was equally priced (15) but was NO WHERE NEAR AS DELICIOUS. (The first place was called 'Cajun Food' or similar on Bourbon street- tourist trap). Anyways, WOW.

It only gets 4 stars because while the bartenders and servers were great, there was too much going on about their daily lives in my face.

The 49ers beat the Saints.
Just happened by this place - checked the great reviews- had the corn and crab bisque- and the crawfish platter - very good!! And service by shane was great!
Wonderful 4 course meal and drinks. Redfish beinets, braised lamb, big oysters.  Nice open air seating by front of restaurant.  Definitely has that New Orleans feel.  Located in the French Quarter.

I really don't understand the positive reviews for this place. The only conclusion I can come to is that so many people probably come here as tourists, you get a wide range of undeveloped palettes and nondiscriminating opinions of service.

The food was super mediocre (crawfish and crab ravioli) that may have been just regular frozen ravioli. The dough was thick, the filling flavorless.

My biggest upset was the service. I sat at the bar and to my horror, considering this is a "nicer" seafood restaurant, was being served by a guy (my check said Larry) who kept referring to me as "sweetheart" and had a full mouth of gold and silver teeth. Talk about my appetite being ruined. Regardless, I blasted through my meal and went to pay...

What the f*ck. I get handed my check and the first words out of Larry's mouth are "Anything you write on here..." (pointing to the tip area on the receipt) "goes into my check, but anything else goes into this bucket back here that I can split at the end of the night" (pointing to the *cash* tip bucket behind the bar). 

Excuse me? Really?

The service was awesome!  There was 6 of us and all of us really enjoyed our experience.  We had the boiled shrimp, seafood stuffed mushrooms, crab and corn chowder, french onion soup.  And the raw oysters on the half shell were super clean and delicious.  It's a must do on my list.

Oh boy oh boy oh boy!  If you come to New Orleans and neglect to go to Royal House for their charbroiled oysters and Bloody Marys then shame shame shame on you!  Gotta thank Kelly S. for the heads up on this one because we had many places to go in a little over 48 hours in New Orleans.  Boy, this joint didn't dissapoint one bit!

I licked the inside of the oyster shells.  Yep, I did and I have absolutely no shame.  Garlic, butter, lemon and a little parmesean cheese.....who the heck wouldn't want to lick that up?  I was boxing people out at the table so I could make sure I had at least one more of those tasty little boogers.

The bloody mary was fantastic!  Nice and spicy, I barely had to add any extra tabasco.  It also comes with some extra veggies;  the obligatory green bean and celery along with some pickled garlic.  Yeah buddy!  At $10 it is a bit pricy though.

I also got a cup of the seafood gumbo which was just okay.  I should have just ordered more of those beautiful oysters!

Do yourself a favor and don't skip this.  Too good to pass up.  Next time I come with a smaller group I'm gonna grab one of those 2 people tables on the balcony overlooking Royal Street.

The food is mediocre. The food is overpriced. I ordered red beans with rice and I am pretty sure they used Nathan's sausage and frozen chicken from the grocery aisle. I have had way better red beans and rice for way less ($$) just around the corner. My girlfriend ordered the shrimp creole and she said it sucked too. I really wouldn't go back here. The location is good. They have balcony seating but overall it's a tourist trap.

Eggplant straws were delicious ( however took about a half an hour and so long that the manager gave them to us free).

Oysters Rockafeller beyond bad- overcooked and an impossible amount of goop on top- how do you mess up a dig that simple?

Crawfish Étouffée devoid was devoid of crawfish and tasters right out of a Campbell's soup can.

Id you must go to this tourist trap then stick to the fried food and save yourself major disappointment.  

Our server was lacking charm, graciousness, and personality!

We came back 4 times during our stay in N.O to sit at the bar, eat oysters (all kinds, raw, charbroiled, etc) and have a few cocktails.   Friendly staff and decor.  Can't go wrong here.  Prices good too.

Good service and I loved the raw oysters but those were definitely the highlights. We got the charbroiled oyster sampler and there was so much breading on the Rockefeller and Parmesan ones that they were practically inedible. Then I got the 'Taste of New Orleans' entree and the jambalaya was served cold. They brought out a warmed up cup of it but it was just not good. Even the bloody mary my wife ordered was bad. Definitely won't be back. I guess there was a reason there was no wait here.

The bloody mary here was perfect. We had raw oysters, buttery crab legs with garlic bread, shrimp po boy, and french onion soup - all were definitely last meal in NOLA worthy... and the best part is there wasn't a wait!  Our server was incredibly nice, too!

Ladies.  Wear white shirt and it most definitely will rain.

Was in town for Mardi Gras.  It was a buddy's bday weekend so an overall contingent of around 20 decided to meet in Nola for Mardi Gras, bday celebrations, general debauchery and well...  Reverting back to 18 and acting like idiots.  Maybe that was all redundant.  I don't care.  

So it was Saturday morning.  Mind you, I was in pain after Thurs night and all day drinkathon Friday.  Not the arthritis in my right ankle from years of soccer pain.  Nope, not that kind of pain.  The ice pick in the temple, dehydration where you don't pee until 4pm kind of pain.  Solution?  Bloody Marys.

So what do I do?  I refuse to hit up Bourbon Street or Harrah's (eventhough I pummeled the Black Jack table into a bloody mess on Friday night).  So I start walking from the Marriott.  Aimlessly at first, but then down Royal.  I have no idea where I'm going.  John H don't care.  John H just wants to eat shit and drink shit.  John H is hurting and wants to curl up like the Honey Badger, but he still don't care.

So I'm walking by this massive police station and reminded of times past in Nola and why I don't goto Bourbon Street even on Mardi Gras anymore.  I keep walking.  In the distance, I see the sign.  It seems like the clouds parted and a ray of sunlight was shining on it.  I figure either the Mardi Gras god's or the devil himself is pushing me towards this place.  Maybe the Mardi Gras god's and Beezlebub are the same entity.  Who cares.

I walk in and I'm literally the only person in there.  It is, afterall, like 10am Nola time.  Shennanigans.  I sit down and ask for my typical Ketel One and Bloody.  They guy behind the bar quickly says, "sure you don't want to try it with the infused vodka"?  He points towards the large jar full of all things peppery, garlic like, etc.  I swear the damn thing had a light under it or maybe my vision was blurry due to lack of hydration.  

I say yes to this.  Not knowing where this beginning of the day would take me.  You see, I'm a gluton for punishment.  I think my liver is just this awesome toy that kind of has a bypass around it.  Put up yellow caution signs "road closed", alcohol please take the detour.  NOPE.  Just punish that sucker even more.  Bloody Mary was the best one I've had in a while.  So good I had two and one is usually all I need before moving on to different alcohol.

Food was next on the list.  Another bartender recommended their Chargrilled Oysters and Crab and Corn Bisque.  "Ok, lady, don't give me any crap.  Is it as good as Drago's or not".  I didn't really say it like that because I think she would've three-finger pimped slapped me, but it was what I was thinking.  She was awesome in her recommendations though.  Ordered that very shit she recommended.  

First, the Crab and Corn Bisque.  I want to free-base this stuff.  Should've gotten the bowl.  Just awesome.  Then I moved onto Chargrilled Oysters.  What happens when you combine large oysters, butter, spices, parmesan cheese and a grille?  You come up with slap your mama good stuff.  Not kidding, I would've slapped my mama if she tried to grab one off my plate.  And yes, they were better than Drago's.

As usual stupidity would allow, I decided to stay there another 3 hours while my friends trickled in.  It was during this time that Mardi Gras monsoon 2012 decided to start.  Have white shirt, will rain.  Thank you to the group of 4 women who came in for lunch wearing white shirts after the deluge started.  Your presence was noted and appreciated by all.

Big eff you to the weather though.  You rained out the Krewe of Tucks parade that we were all riding in.  

Good stuff.  Try this place.  Pretty damned cool and that upstairs balcony would be awesome during Friday happy hour or Saturday/Sunday afternoon.

Tortorici's Italian Restaurant used to occupy this same location, and while Royal House is an improvement (my meal at Tortorici's in ~2002 was ruined by a mouse running across the floor at our table), I was personally quite disappointed with my meal.

The restaurant had a Mardi Gras menu, but of course did not post it online, so we chose this restaurant based on the regular menu.  When we sat down and they handed me this menu with only a couple choices, I was quite disappointed that they had removed the only dishes I was going to want.  I ended up ordering the French Onion Soup and a Caprese Salad because they were literally the only things on the Mardi Gras menu that I'd eat (I hate seafood...we chose this restaurant because it had Oysters and didn't have the insane line that Acme has). The soup was okay, though I did like that it had a lot of cheese, it definitely did not have a flavor that stood out as anything but a TGI Friday's quality soup.  The Caprese Salad was not only far too small, but it had onions on it.  What?  Onions on Caprese?  That is weird.  Plus, the restaurant didn't serve bread with the meal, nor with my soup or my Salad.  I requested bread and they charged me $2.50.  

Also, the wine selection is pretty bad.  It's basically only bottles that you can get at Trader Joe's for $10 or less.  Not a single decent wine on the list.  

A funny thing happened though.  The women I was with think that the place is haunted.  One of them said she felt someone grab her arm (she screamed out of nowhere) and two of the other women said they saw something moving at that moment.  They asked the Waitress is weird things happen there and she had all kinds of stories.  So maybe if you're into the occult this place is a good option.  Also, the Crawfish Etouffee and Oysters got good reviews from the ladies in my party, but I'm basing my review on my own meal.

Definitely a better option than Acme Oyster House for tourists during peak times like Jazz Fest or Mardi Gras.  No need to wait in the line at Acme when Royal House has Oysters in a better location without the line.

I am totally a tourist. First time in NOLA and Mardi Gras virgin (nothing could have prepared me for that drunken madness! LOL). This restaurant ended up being our last meal in New Orleans and I think it was a good choice. We had a hankering for Oysters and a lot of the restaurants were closed due to the holiday. Royal House was open however and ready for business. When we initially got there we were told out party of 6 would have to wait 15 minutes. They seated us almost immediately. We sat upstairs, although not on the balcony sadly. Those char grilled oysters were amazing! Amazing! Butter, garlic, lemon and Parmesan. I sopped that juice right up with slices of french bread. So so good! I ordered the shrimp and scallop paste which was really good. Lots of fresh seafood and in a sauce that didn't taste too heavy (although I'm sure it won't be winning any "healthy heart" awards!). The boyfriend had the Louisiana Trio, shrimp creole, etouffee and rice and beans. They were all delicious. Had a bite of the bread pudding and it was really good - I'm not a big sweet eater to can't be relied upon for reviews of those. Priscilla, our server was very nice, friendly and quick. I really liked this place. If I'm ever back in NOLA I will go there!

Stopped by for oysters on the half shell.
Outstanding. Good service and presentation.
Enjoyed a few dozen with some Chardonay. 
Finished It off with some excellent gumbo soup
Very casual and open through numerous doors to the street so you can watch the people

Hubby and I were in town for Mardi Gras and on Monday I was jonesing to sit on a balcony and do a bit of people watching. We kept scanning the rafters and saw that Royal House had seating for two on their balcony so we ascended and were seated immediately on what ended up being a bit of a precocious creaky balcony. We were treated to the sights and sounds of Mardi Gras: there were a number of high fa-looting summer suit wearing ladies and dapper dressed gentlemen getting (including the mayor!) out of their posh rides to head over to Antoine's for krewe lunch. We witnessed the interesting politics of street entertainment where a tarot reader, a juggling act, and a five piece band were negotiating street spots and who got to set up where. And finally there were the weirdos of MG, dressed in all sorts of attire and in varying degrees of stupor at 10am. The waiter was very pleasant and chatty, just a clock-out away from full on fishing attire. Those are the highlights. We ordered a mojito, hurricane, shrimp po-boy, and a Caresse salad. My husband liked his po-boy and it was definitely sizable. My salad was okay and the mojito left a lot to be desired. For so many good places to eat in NOLA, the food here is not worth the calories.

Bottom Line: Come with your plus 1 and order some cokes to enjoy people watching from the balcony.

My last meal (lunch) in NOLA. 

After reading about Royal as an "up and comer" on the French Quarter Gumbo scene, I decided to give it a try while winding down my touristy Thursday.

The bartender recommended the chicken and sausage gumbo, advice which I readily accepted...accompanied by a Bloody Mary of course. 

Tasty and cheap (except for my $10 bloody, which was more than my bowl of gumbo...wtf?) it got the job done.

As I was wrapping up my meal the bartender provides me with a quote that sums up New Orleans perfectly:

"Hey my man, I'm not rushing you at all, but you do know that's a to go cup, right?"

Oh New Orleans, how I love thee.

We had 4 waiters bringing water, the food, taking our order and clearing plates. Wow. They were all very nice and called us "sir" and "ma'am". 

The red beans and rice was actually really good. I don't know why I thought it might be bland but there was a decent spice to it. The catfish po boy looked amazing, biggest piece of catfish I saw on a po boy all week.

I'd go back here for sure. Be aware that the menu in house is different than the current website PDF.

Late afternoon so after the lunch rush and before dinner crowds, the place was not busy.  We asked for an outdoor balcony table, which was nice but also a bit scary.  Sitting outside, they don't serve your drinks in glassware just in case you drop them.

We had 2 dozens of oyster.  I had some flavored martini and hubby had the Abita amber.  Service was lacking since the waitress was spending all of her time yapping with a friend than tending to her customers.
My husband & I were looking for some late night food that was not on Bourbon St, and we found Royal House. Excellent service, and outstanding food.

I had half dozen raw oysters here today and enjoyed them thoroughly.  The speciality drinks were all $10 so I passed and got out for $8 before tip.  The service was friendly too.  I would go there again for the same thing or something different.

We came here for our last meal yesterday, and since we wanted some oysters, this seemed to be the place, especially since they had oysters rockefeller, and I had been wanting to try. We were unable to sit upstairs outside as there were 6 of us, and they're only in tables of 2. It's a cute restaurant, with a large bar in the front, and areas where people can sit in twos while looking out at the street and people watch.

Our waitress recommended the honey Jack Daniels with lemonade, and since I'm a huge fan of Jack Daniels, I had to try. It's sweet, but not overbearingly sweet, but I couldn't taste the alcohol at all, or feel it? Although there must have been some as my friend had the asian glow afterwards. 

We ordered 4 different types of oysters. A dozen raw, half a dozen of the rockefeller, a dozen of the chargrilled, and oysters royale.

The raw oysters had a saltier taste than others, more brimey, and I found a mini pearl as I was eating one, or chewed on it and thought maybe I broke a tooth. Nice little souvenier, nor did I know you could find pearls in oysters!

The oysters rockefeller was dissapointing. It was just a baked bready oyster, and I was thinking it would be like the chargrilled, but with spinach and herbs. Not what I had expected at all. The royale was the same, but more seafoody. The chargrilled oysters, you can't go wrong with all the butter and garlic and parmesean cheese. Yum!

My friend's gumbo was tasty, and the seafood portofino had a great sauce. My alligator po boy was okay, not the greatest, but the fries were coated in this extra batter that was pure deliciousness.
