Reason for 3 stars is the raw oysters were our least favorite out of the 4 places we've tried, and service was lackluster. Very slow, and we were in a rush to get to the airport.

Turned away from Chartres House Cafe (at 8:30pm, WTF), they recommended their sister restaurant, Royal House. Love Royal Street! It's quieter, full of art galleries, and had a violinist/drum combo in the middle of the street that was killing it! (With Police escort- I might add...)

Royal House seated our group of five in no time! It's a casual place where you can sample some good New Orleans cuisine, especially seafood. My group raved about the oysters! I don't do oysters, but one newbie even enjoyed them. 

Service here is very friendly and relaxed. The oyster-dropping guy was clowning with our table, and I like that. Keepin' it realz, Royalz. Most of us were intrigued by the Taste of New Orleans Sampler of Gumbo, Etouffe, and Jambalaya. The Jambalaya was great, nice and spicy! I got the chicken and sausage gumbo, which was very good- and my dining partners subbed for the seafood gumbo, which they said was a alright, a little fishy. The Etouffe was the star of the sampler, and had little crawfish (crayfish, yadda yadda), in it. I'm not a fan of shellfish, but the broth, the tiny crawfish- everything about this was great!

Others in my group raved about the Shrimp Creole, and the Baked Seafood Tortellini in red sauce- which looked amazing!

This place is casual-nice- fans of seafood and oysters will love it! And everyone in our group was satisfied by our meal. It's all happening! On Royal Street!

My wife and I stopped here for a quick afternoon snack and we were very pleased. We had a dozen oysters, which were excellent, and the the shrimp boil, which was also excellent. The service was good, and the beers were very cold!

Food:
Charbroiled oysters: oysters in butter, parsley, parmesan: $15 per dozen 
Corn crab bisque: $10 a bowl
Crawfish + crab ravioli with crawfish sauce: $19
Grilled redfish: $22

All very very yummy, loved the redfish (I had the ravioli, which was quite good), which was meaty and flavorful. The bisque was creamy but not too rich or salty with wonderful seafood flavor. This was our spendiest meal, and though pricey, everything was so so good. 

We got a table in a window that opened onto the street, and we were treated to a nice serenade on the opposite corner during dinner.

This place tastes and serves so well. Can't hate.

Although some other reviewers placed this as a tourist trap, I'm actually more than happy to admit I would come here again.

Location and setup : It was a little bit of a walk but about 0.1 mi from our hotel. This is a hilarious distance for me but for my parents aged 5x, hungry, and after a long day of exploring the Mississippi River they were a little against walking far. Mom, why did you try to wear heeled sandals? I know it's a trend but they're not going to make you anywhere close to 5' 1". Anyhow I digress, it's close to the river and close to Canal. Which is great plus it's quiet enough away from bourbon street to talk to your party.

Food : We had --

Crawfish Etouffee ($14.95) the waiter recommended adding fried crawfish ontop. So we had DOUBLE the amount of crawfish. It was so good, I actually thought it would be like shepherd's pie but the rice soaked the moisture of the sauce. It's good, but if you're not into stew-y food or wet foods you should pick something else. Best way to describe it for me was Arroz con Pollo cept Crawfish instead of chicken.

Alligator Poboy ($12.95) alligator meat is sour and salty. Be prepared but my dad actually enjoyed it alot. Then again he loves salt. It tastes like grilled then fried lemon tilapia to me. Tilapia because it's white meat and still has that slight fish taste. It was good plus their seasons (double fried???) french fries were good.

Shrimp Poboy ($10.95) Classic is still a goodie. They do it right and affordable. Generous amount of friends and a very fresh bread to tag along. Good stuff!

Chargrilled Oysters ($15 for dozen) oh my god, I don't eat oysters but I had to try these. SO GOOD SO SOO GOOD. You must you must! I wish I had a drink to pair with it but since I'm out with the parents we're not allowed to drink. Buzzkill.

Banana Foster Cheesecake ($6.95) very pretty and presented well. It was delicious and now I'm hooked on Banana Foster ANYTHING. Thank god I packed skirts and dresses instead of skinny jeans.

Love the food, ambiance, live music, spacious seating and great location, but the most important to me regarding an outing with the folks was the service. My waiter was from Los Angeles and moved here and he's a very sharp guy. Speaks a bit of Korean, Japanese (from his time working in Beni Hana), French, and Spanish. He was very nice, quick, polite, and he actually came to our table without food to have a chat with us. My parents forgot about the aches in their feet and the walk or the loud crowds from Bourbon we had to pass, and just cared about the good food, music, and the light conversation.

In all, including our lemonades and a single beer plus tip the meal costs us about $90. Not bad at all for a party of 4.

My Husband and I were in New Orleans for the final four. We came upon this Rest. by chance just walking around the French Quarter.. What a great find.. This little gem has the most amazing Oyster Bar.. 
 
My husband had the Red fish, which was amazing, in fact he said it was the best fish he had ever had..  I had the grilled Oysters, Amazing.  If we had more time we would have gone back and tried all of the oysters dishes. 

And thanks to our most gracious waiter, Tim, we ordered the Bread Pudding.  We never order desert, but thanks to his recommendation and great suggestions, we had the best meal in a long time.  

Thank You Royal House and especially Tim for making our New Orleans trip so great, as our team lost.. 

We will definitely visit Royal House on our next visit..

A nice place for lunch, dinner, or just a few Oysters. The staff was incredibly nice, our waitress Colette was helpful and kind. Gave us a few ideas of things to do that night. If she is your server ask how Siete is doing.

This may be my favorite place in the French quarter. We went here two nights in a row for dinner. Friday with a party of four, we sat inside and were all very impressed by the quick staff and the great food. I had a gator po boy, some gumbo and eggplant fries. I also had a few of my friend's oysters on the half shell and man were they good. As a matter of fact the only thing that didn't hit five stars were the eggplant fries but maybe it was just because they were drown out by how awesome everything else was.

Saturday night I came back for a romantic balcony dinner. The view was beautiful and you could really soak the city in from a great vantage point. 

I drank the best bloody marry I've ever had. It was magic. We did the gumbo again and this time she git a shrimp po boy and I did the oyster sampler. Everything was perfect and I find myself sad i can't go back in the near future.

This place was sooo promising.

Great location.  Spacious.  Second story balcony to occasionally pop out and see a Second Line coming down the street.  Wide windows open to let a nice breeze through while dining.  

I mean...it is set up to not fail.

Unfortunately, there is a staff.  

While, most of the time the staff was friendly and accommodating they were not knowledgeable nor had any sense of urgency.  Getting a server was pretty damn difficult for our 10 top.  Getting a busser was pretty damn difficult.  getting more rounds of drinks ... was the hardest.  This should be actually the easiest.  

ANY server who knows anything wants to up-sale their table with booze as much as possible.  The tip increases as the bill increases.  The bill increases due to more drinks ordered.  More drinks ordered when you're around to ask or even check on the table.  Pretty easy...usually.

Then..the grub was really hit or miss.  The Po-Boys need a lot less bread.  The gumbos and other soups were amazing.  ... tough to really gauge what is going on when ten different orders all had a varying amount of satisfaction.

Overall, if you're in a pinch for dinner with no plans...you may want to swing by here...you'll most likely have a meh time.

Six ladies visiting NOLA had dinner here two nights in a row.  We sat inside and had very good service and even better food.  The charbroiled oysters are wonderful!  We had great spinach salads:  one with grilled scallops, one with grilled shrimp and one with fried oysters - all wonderful.  Also had great corn and crab bisque.   We were seated immediately both nights and highly recommend this restaurant.

While in New Orleans, we had planned on going to places like Acme Oyster House and Drago's for Charbroiled oysters.  However, after one of the tour guides told us that the local ate at Royal House, we decided to go there instead--wasn't disappointed!  The oysters were amazing!  Although I have to admit that I can't vouch for the other places to compare it to, but still phenomenal charbroiled oysters.  We sat at the bar and also enjoyed the company of the "bartender", which was very pleasant as well.

Great place to swing by for a bite, even if not for a full meal. Good prices too. Raw oysters for a buck each! Not highly unusual around here but it's a rare find back home in San Francisco so I was happy.

The Royal House supplied the best oysters that I had the whole time that I was in New Orleans. As far as a full service restaurant to get dinner there are many choices in the area that will be just as good, but for oysters I didn't find better. It is an oyster bar after all.

We sampled all the oysters they had on the menu and they were all delicious. I am used to the ones we get on the West coast, which are very good, but I felt like I have never experienced all these crustaceans have to offer until I made it to the Gulf. So plump, sweet and full of flavor!!

The favorites of the group in order:
Charbroiled (better than Drago's)
Raw
Royale
Rockefellar
Pepperino

Great staff and they had no problem splitting the bill across three separate cards.
Fantastic service, nice ambiance. Our server Colette recommended the Charbroiled oysters with a tossed salad, and we were not disappointed. Right down the street from the Chart Room, too!

In a single weekend we managed to stop in here in two separate occasions, for oysters, for that French fried eggplant straws, and for their delicious cajun Bloody Mary. Yeah, we became fast fans.

This Oyster Bar, Royal House for short, seemly tiny and insufficient spacing at first, giving you a sense of constant full house if they fill up the bar and window seats; looking closer,  you will see that it stands at the busiest corner at Royal St and Burbon St, and you can find plenty more tables hiding away in the back, and also the balcony if you are fortunate.

Let's get right down to the salty and slimy, shall we? Of course I'm talking about the oysters. They are not bad at all, though I wished they can take a few more moments to let the shell rinse off a bit more. At least when you get them on half-shelves, fresh or  charbroiled, they are equally tasty. If you cannot decide, try the trio of Rockefeller, Royal, and Pepperino then.

As I mentioned, oysters were not their only trick in the pony stable; any other dishes on the menu can induce drooling at an instant. Oh, to finish your meal, if you plan ahead and actually still able, I would recommend the banana foster cheesecake.

It really makes me sad that I can't be here every weekend. Oysters are my thing so after dinning there, I  felt like I found my place. It felt right! And for things to feel right, the food, the service, the way the place looks, location and the whole package got to be right, right?! this place takes it!  The servers are hot 2! Like, I cant believe this! 


It was a Friday night, the first floor dinning area was packed so we assumed we wil be waiting around but when we got there, the guy was like follow me! They have a second floor dinning area with big windows and balcony. We sat in the balcony watching the guys on the street play music. I can't tell you how good it felt! I had half dozen of cooked and uncooked Oyster. I had a Hurricane and it was great! 

Oh how can I forget about the homemade putting. Words cant explain!

Came in here to watch the Derby - somewhere a bit quieter and off of Bourbon.  A good mix of tourists and locals.  They were very accommodating for all of us wanting to watch the Derby.  Gumbo was ok.  My dad loved his oysters.  The spinach and artichoke dip was delicious.  The best thing about this place I would have to say is the wait staff.  They were great and so helpful!

Came here with a large group on the first night of a 3 night trip to the city. 

Ordered oysters 3 ways - raw, charred, and rockafeller. I'm not a huge fan of oysters, but when in Rome.... all 3 were very tasty in their own ways. If I were to return here again, I think I'd just get charred. 

On to the main course - I went for the crab n crawfish ravioli, several people said it was the best plate at the table. It was very rich, but not overwhelming. I'm a huge seafood fan, and this place was a great way to kick off the trip!
Don't bother with this place. Food was only warm and not that great  Watch out for the tip. They included the tip in the bill and we only had 5 in the party.

We have been to NOLA 4 times and have walked by this "tourist" place about 100 times. We have even stayed right across the street a couple of times. 

We wanted some dinner late one night and our choices were really limited to tourist spots so we decided to give the Royal House a shot. We were very happy we did. We had a great table out on the balcony and both got the shrimp creole. I have to say,I may not be an expert on shrimp creole, but this stuff was very tasty. The shirmp ws cooked perfectly and the dish had a good level of spice without blowing you away,just enough. 

We would hit the Royal House again for sure

There are some times when you get the perfect dining experience. This would be one of those times. After spending all day at Jazz Fest we were short on time before going to another show so we didn't get a chance to eat. By the time we left the show it was closing in on midnight. New Orleans is not like Manhattan where dinner time is somewhere between 9 and 10 o'clock and resturants continue to serve late into the night . Things were starting to close and Sara and I were worried about quality places to eat. 

We had walked by Royal House several times before on our walks around town but usually had other places to go. Famished and delirious, (not really) we walk to the front door and ask in our best David Copperfield orphan voices if they were serving. The young man at the door noticed our plight and in the most nonchalant way I've ever heard, as if we asked him if he had bubble gum, "Sure".

Leading us to a table along the street side of the restaurant we were seated in listening distance and visual view of a street performer playing Rolling Stones covers with lots of audience participation. It actually sounded pretty good and was entertaining to watch. Our waiter, Tim (the kind soul who seated us), brought out our menus and asked how we were and what kind of shananagins we had been up to. After some short banter he got to the specials and was very pleasant to talk to. 

Once we ordered our food came out really quickly. I got the fried clams with pasta which was awesome. Not only cause I really hadn't eaten all day but because it was so flavorful. Everything was fresh not just the clams but the sauce as well. I wish I could remember what Sara got but I do remember it being very good. Tim was attentive and when there was time even chatted with us for a few minutes. 

We really enjoyed ourselves and even though we were stuffed and exhausted from the day we wished to stay, but it was obvious that they were finally getting ready to close. When I come back to NOLA I will defiantly stop by here again and try some more of what they have to offer. Have to say was the best meal I had in my stay.

We were told to come here for the oysters, and they didnt disappoint.  So if you like oysters, listen to the reviews. As far as the other food, the stuffed mushrooms were super delicious and were way better than most places we've tried. Never have luck with stuffed mushrooms...anyway, the po-boy was decent but could've done without.  Hope this helps fellow yelpers!
This was a really nice place for a quick lunch.  I had their crab and corn bisque and it was fantastic.  I will definitely come back next time I'm in town.

I'm going to preface this review by acknowledging that I am deathly allergic to seafood - to the point where I'm more proficient with an EpiPen than most people are with a toothbrush. What then, might you ask, was I doing in an oyster house in the middle of New Orleans?  For the sake of love, of course. I had the opportunity to dine at Royal House for a friend's wedding reception and thoroughly enjoyed myself, regardless of the fact that I didn't ingest a single ounce of oysters.

Food: Royal House specializes in fresh oysters and seafood, but the menu also includes an assortment of non-surf appetizers, soups, salads, and entrees. A set buffet was offered for the reception that I attended, which included cheese, fruit, mini muffulettas, duck quesadillas, gumbo, and the restaurant's famed oysters. I found all the options to be fresh, well-prepared, and flavorful. Although I didn't try the oysters, they were literally flying off the tray immediately upon delivery, so I can only assume that they were perfectly delightful. 

Service: Every staff member, from the bartenders to the banquet staff, was personable, professional, and efficient. They were also fairly proficient at replenishing the dishes in a timely manner, particularly the oysters.  

Atmosphere: Royal House is located in a historic building in the heart of the French Quarter. The restaurant is located on two separate floors - the oyster bar occupies most of the first floor, while an additional dining room and outdoor patio are located on the second floor.  I was told by the staff that the restaurant that originally occupied this building, Tortorici's, frequently hosted Hollywood elites like Frank Sinatra and Dean Martin.

Cost: The regular food menu is moderately priced. Appetizers are $8-$11, soups and salads are $6-$13, po-boys and sandwiches are $10-$15, entrees are $15-$25, and desserts are $6-$8. Raw oysters are $7/half dozen and $12/dozen, while charbroiled oysters are $8/half dozen and $15/dozen.

Other: Hours of operation are Monday-Friday, 11AM-12AM, and Saturday-Sunday, 9AM-12AM. Breakfast is served on the weekends from 9AM-11AM. 18% gratuity is added to parties of 5 or more.

A dozen raw oysters, half a dozen grilled oysters with Parmesan cheese and lemon, and a nice bottle of chardonnay is pure joy.  Add to it a great indoor/outdoor seating area and you have near perfection.

As we sat at the bar with the open/windows we enjoyed the sounds of the street music and the hustle of the bar - it was almost was perfect.  

But then...   our waiter wasn't all that friendly and the food was just okay - we shared oysters and a catfish po'boy.   Both were fine, but not the best.  We enjoyed the atmosphere most...

Memorial day weekend. We wanted to eat somewhere else but then we stumbled on this place. We had 4 ppl for dinner, the line was out the door. We were told 15 mins, checked back at 15 mins and told another 15 mins. It took an hour to get seated. 
Do they care? Hell to the no. why?? well because when its a touristy place, why would you? you don't get repeat clients so why care. 

I ordered the charbroiled oysters, they were really tasty but some how one was over cooked *shrugs* still confused on that one. 

From what I saw the food looks good but not some where I would wait an hour to eat. 

This place left a bad taste in my mouth before we ever sat down.

Great experience at this place. Sat on a lopsided balcony, but felt safe and had great views of the French Quarter.

Checked in on Yelp App and received free appetizer. Got the stuffed mushrooms. Nice treat.

Met some friends here to have a drink and experienced great service!

This is a great stop in the quarter located on the corner of St. Louis and Royal Street.  There is a host to seat you if you want to grab a bite, but also a really long bar if you just want to saddle up and knock some back.  This place really does a good job of balancing restaurant and bar.

Our waitress was great.  Lots of personality; she checked on us frequently without interrupting our flow.  I love the way she explained the drink specials, describes not only the ingredients, but the process in which the drink is made and information about the region/origin of the beverage.  I think the extra effort set the tone for time at this watering hole.  I settled for the New Castle Summer Ale, which was great for this particularly hot day.  

There are usually artists in the area, so try and sit by the window for added amusement.  The mojitos looked really good, but like I said, I had a beer.  We had raw oysters and they were great.

Looking forward to stopping in again!

This place was pretty much alright. My wife and I split a pretty good crab appetizer. I got the shrimp creole, which had some pretty good shrimp but was essentially just boiled shrimp, tomato sauce, and rice. I found it good but a bit boring. My wife got the crawfish etoufee, which was pretty good, but not as good as we've had at other places. We were not disappointed eating here, but didn't find it that great either.

I went here for lunch today and I was very pleasantly surprised!! I am always a little wary of any place in the quarter that looks too "touristy" or has plated samples of the food displayed under saran wrap on the host podium out front - I mean come on!  BUT just recently I have heard some great things from some of my more discerning friends so I thought I'd give it a whirl!  I am so glad I did.  Great atmosphere!  The space is really open with a lot of light and all the french doors created a nice cross breeze even though was 95 degrees outside!  Very pleasant and relaxing.  It's a perfect people watching spot.  I sat at the bar and had a lovely conversation with the very attentive bartender then I ordered the Spinach Salad with Blackened Scallops and I dare say it was EXCELLENT!

The only complaint - there are no special lunch prices and they don't have a "Happy Hour!" :(

The food was all around delicious. We ordered the corn and crab chowder to start, oh my gosh I could eat the whole pot it was so fresh. For entrees we got Salmon and Crab Bercy and the Baked Seafood Tortellini, we polished off our plates! The waitress was very friendly and helpful in explaining the menu and giving suggestions. It was a great setting for a date night and we sat right by a couple of the doors that opened to the street.
Fabulous jambalaya. Service was poor to average however food made up for it! If you're close by give it a try

This place is great. Great food, great atmosphere, great service. Loved everything about it. I got the linguine with clams which was excellent and my friend had the crabmeat and crawfish ravioli which was even better. Would definitely recommend this restaurant. It is a little pricey, but it is worth it.

Unscrupulous manager alert.
Small Kine... Axe To Grind!

We asked if we could use two yelp coupons for two appetizers for our party of 4 and were told that we could by our otherwise wonderful server. So with this information, we ordered two appetizers with our 4 entrees and 6 drinks. At the end of our meal, we were told that a mistake had been made and that we would have to pay for one appetizer. We said this was bait and switch and was not acceptable. 

After making us wait a long time, and being treated politely by us...the manager (Stephanie) lied to us about how it was impossible for her to discount the appetizers and rudely said there was nothing she could do other than make the server pay for the other appetizer. Really? How about this...don't put the appetizer on the bill! Or just treat us as if we were at two separate tables! Don't make up excuses about your food billing system. AND DON'T LIE TO US! 

Stephanie, you ruined what was otherwise a very nice dinner for us with your obstinacy and small mindedness over 10 frickin dollars. I hope that perhaps an owner or manager will read this and have a talk with you about your poor attitude. If so, perhaps you could request additional customer service training and learn to treat people better? I gave you every chance to do the right thing and your choice was to lie to me and blame and threaten your server.  That's weak sauce.

Otherwise...the food was pretty good. Our server gave us the wrong info on the appetizers and kind of screwed up our order but he was polite and helpful so he gets a pass on that. The atmosphere was ok. If it weren't for the customer service fail...I would say 3.5 stars.

The service was excellent on a Friday afternoon. The sautéed crab fingers are out of this world (you'll want more bread just to sop up the rest of the sauce). But the poyboys (shrimp & crawfish) left much to be desired. The gumbo was less than great.

We tried this for something different.  Not a place we had been before.  Food was very good.   We had oysters and crab claws.  There was a couple there with their little girl, maybe 6 years old, and the chef came out and was really cute with her.  Atmosphere is very laid back.  Nice experience.

The food is was delicous and so was the atmosphere, but the waiter not so much.
We were a group of five, we all order and when the food came out  two dishes were incorrect. One had the blackened Redfish with crab meat topping the other just Redfish grilled. When they came out one fish was blackened with crab meat but they gave it to the person that orderered just grilled, and the other person got just a redfish blackened. When this was pointed out, both dishes were taken back to the kitchen.
When the dishes returned, they had scraped the crab meat off on redfish meal and put it on the other . Keeping in mind both fish were blackened. Again we pointed out that the other fish was blackened and not grilled and that we could tell that the crab meat had been scraped off one fish to go on the other and he denied it. We gave him an out and he played the I didn't know the other fish was blackend too and denied the crab meat sitution, even though we could clealy see pieces of crab meat on the fish. Needless to say they finally fixed the sitution, reluctantly.

The Tast of New Orleans was yummy and the grilled and blackended redfish was good too. Just watch your food.

I visited Royal House for dinner on a weekday in May. It is not a very large place and seating was fairly limited.  But nothing special was happening in New Orleans that week and the crowds were very light.  I was seated immediately by a window next to the bar.

The waiter was very pleasant and he got us started with drinks.  I had read about the Bloody Mary's , so I had to have one.  It was very tasty and perfectly seasoned for my taste.  I don't like it when they just taste like hot sauce.

The spicy tomato drink went well with the appetizers that we had.  The crawfish cakes, crab claws and charbroiled oysters were all very good.   In fact the charbroiled oysters were so good I went back the next day for more before going out for drinks.  I highly recommend them.  They are much better than oysters Rockefeller which I had always liked.
 
When I checked in on Yelp I was pleasantly surprised to see a check-in offer for a free appetizer.  (Thus the third appetizer when there were only two of us.)  Unfortunately, they would have been better off not offering it because it was the cause of the only problem I had with the place.  At first the waiter had to go and check with the manager to determine if I met some qualifications for redeeming the offer.  The later when the bill came, the discount had not been applied.  With the trouble I had to go through to get the offer in the first place, I wasn't going to let this slide so I asked the waiter to try again.  The bill was finally corrected.  I don't know if it was the manager or the waiter to blame for this, but it tarnished an otherwise good experience.

My entrees were also delicious.  I don't remember exactly what I ate, but my notes said that I like it a lot.

So overall, the food was very good and the service was mostly good.  I would definitely go back to Royal House.

Everyone is really friendly here. The door staff make you feel welcome right off the bat. Waiters very knowledgable and hospitable. Bloody Mary's are AWESOME and a must try. Po-boy's are great but sub out something else for fries. Also, try the étouffée with fried crawfish tails sprinkled on top - best I have ever had. I usually eat here twice when I visit NOLA. Try it.

Great Service and very good food.
My wife and I came here for lunch on a Sunday afternoon.  We were greeted outside by a friendly guy and  were seated promptly.
  They had an interesting cocktail list and it was revealed to my wife that all of the cocktails were going to be pretty sweet. This wasn't too surprising since we were one block off of bourbon street.  We both decided to try one but my wife's was undrinkable. So they offered her a glass of white wine instead which was much more palatable for her.
   We ordered 1/2 dozen charbroiled oysters and 1 dozen raw oysters.  All the food was very good and the service all around was great.  The waiter even took off the drink that my wife could no drink.  
  Great food but stay away from the cocktail list on the menu if you don't like super sweet drinks. The service was spot on as well.

On 07/20/12 we visited the Royal House Oyster Bar and had a wonderful time.  The area is very cozy and when we were there not too crowded.  We had the Eggplant Straws as an app. with our drinks and when it comes to drinks Ryan did a fantastic job!  We had the Voodoo Juice, Bayou Bell, a Bloody Mary and the local beer. The Bloody Mary was EXCELLENT!  Nice place and great service...Ryan Rocked!
Our waiter was really good. Tables were packed close. I got kind of claustrophobic. I got some kind of ravioli with a beauxbridge sauce. It was excellent.

Balcony is slanted so sit inside if you do not want the v8 experience. Stumbled upon this great restaurant with my sparkling beautiful girlfriend. Great elegant atmosphere with super choice of appetizers. Great pasta!

Please hear me good residents and visitors of New Orleans!  The Sauteed Crab Claws are, hands down, one of the most amazing dishes I have EVER been fortunate enough to have.  It is Heaven in your mouth.  My travel-mate and I were recommended this dish by a absolutely enjoyable waitress (said she takes them home every night to her husband and they are addicted to them).  She was not messing around.  The Oyster Trio was also divine and of course their Hurricanes, but the dish that forever lingers on my taste buds, and the dish that makes me itch to get back to N.O a.s.a.p are their Sauteed Crab Claws.  Perfection!

I literally cannot believe that in all my visits to nola, and living here for 2.5 years during grad school, during which I hit up the quarter nonstop, that I haven't ever been to royal house!

My boyfriend spotted royal house and their oyster sign when we were wandering late night, and we returned the next evening for some drinks and oysters post wine at bar vin.  While we had a snafu with our waiter and order (he wasn't too accommodating when he brought the wrong drink, but we worked it out with a manager), and the oysters and drinks were certainly not especially quick, $1 oysters is dirt cheap by nyc standards (albeit not necessarily nola standards), and the place was pretty packed/popular.  It was dark at the point we got there, but it seemed like a cute/cozy old fashioned new orleans ambiance - plus an upstairs (which was vacant), should it get too packed on the main level.

I'll absolutely return in the future!

Thanks to Yelp, this one was one of my favorite meals in NOLA.  We sat up on the balcony eating the tastes of the south.  My buddy ChuBear had a shrimp POBOY and he was in heaven.  I had the eggplant sticks (like Mozz sticks with eggplant) and they were on target man.  I also had their version of a caprese salad, which they made into a tour and that was really good; the basil and the mozzarella was so fresh.  Chubear and I split the MOST AMAZING DESERT EVER:  Bananas Foster Cheesecake.  Holy cow I nearly died.

I would definitely go here if you are in NOLA.

We stopped here for Bloody Marys in the morning and then came back for lunch. My friends had the charbroiled oysters and some plain. I had the crawfish cakes. Everything was awesome and the staff was super attentive and friendly.

I came here around lunch time on a friday. Great service and the food was good too. I love the decor and the look of the restaurant. They had a lot of seatings with an upstairs and even a balcony to eat outside. Unfortunately it was raining so we couldn't enjoy our meal on the balcony. 

We first ordered half raw oysters and half charbroiled as the appetizers. It tasted just delish, too bad they don't have happy hour for drinks and oysters.

Next I had the oyster platter, (yes i went oyster crazy that day). It came with fries, hush puppies, and sauce. The platter was really big and was more than enough I could eat. 

I love how they have their oyster bar menu, I will def come back to try their oyster trio.

During the French Quarter fest this past spring,  I had one of the better shrimp and grits dishes I had ever had and my girlfriend had some delicious crawfish cakes.  So last week (8/18/12) we happened to be walking by and figured we would stop in for lunch.  I was absolutely shocked when I saw a "Barker " at the front door.  My tourist trap radar immediately went up but memories of the shrimp and grits were far to powerful. We were seated immediately and given menus. Neither dish was anywhere in site (I didn't expect crawfish cakes since out of season but I figured crab cakes) .  I just settled for a shrimp poboy and my girlfriend had the chicken and andoille gumbo. The poboy and fries arrived and my fries were really a fry as they were all stuck together. The poboy was constructed funny as you couldn't get a bite of everything. Some bites were just bread, lettuce, and tomato. There were not enough shrimp.

The wait staff was friendly and they are fast but too many other places serving far better food in the area.

Excellent!  Had the boil with lobster, stuffed mushrooms, bloody mary, and bread pudding for dessert.  All top notch, everything seasoned just right, and cooked to perfection.  

Service was great as well.  Substituted out my muscles with more clams no problem.  Very pleasant and accommodating. 

We were in NOLA for two days, and this was the best place we ate.
Fantastic charbroiled oysters and cocktails. Bread pudding is a must as well! Everything gave us multiple mouth-gasms :D Super friendly staff and Tim was an awesome server!

The Crab Claws were phenomenal.  I wish I could have had a bigger serving. What ever the sauce is that they saute them in tasted great.  The Chicken Marsala that my Fiance ordered was very tender and full of flavor. Servers were very personable and helpful. Food was served quickly.

This place was so good that I never write reviews and I'm writing one now. Incredible restaurant! Friendly and entertaining staff, delicious food and great service!

Loved the Seafood Stuffed Mushrooms, Crab & Corn Bisque and Crawfish Etouffee! Everything was so flavorful that I didn't even feel the need to put hot sauce on anything, and I put hot sauce on everything.

All of the waiters and staff were incredibly friendly and the manager even came out to ask how everything was. Joe was our actual waiter and he was very observant and kind. We rarely had to ask for anything. Tim was pretty cool, too. Although he wasn't our waiter, he provided some good entertainment for the night.

Overall I was very pleased and impressed with the place. Plus, when you check-in here you get a free appetizer ($9.95 or less) with a purchase of an entree!

Great first meal in New Orleans! Would definitely recommend it. :)
Had a good late afternoon oyster run here yesterday before dinner.  Oysters were fresh.  Try if acme too busy.

OMG! this place was amazing!  We popped in here on a whim and it was a gold mine of yummy food.  The BEST dish i had on my entire vacation in New Orleans was here; the crab claws in a creamy garlic sauce.  It was delicious!!!!!

As we were walking down the street, drinks in hand like almost everyone else in NOLA,  this place welcomed us in drinks and all.  The waiter was cute and friendly, thanks Dave! The crawfish etouffee was phenomenal!  The gumbo was very good but ACME's was better.  My fiance got the fried oysters, they were great with the cocktail sauce.  I would highly reccommend trying this place!

Not a huge fan of seafood in general, but my friend was in the mood for oysters so we went.  What a great surprise.  We had the chargrilled ones soaked in butter and garlic -- how can you go wrong with that?  Then I ordered the pasta with deep fried oysters and I have to say, I think I am a convert.  They were so dang good, I am starting to drool just writing this review.  We ate at the bar and the bartender was busy but never neglected us and I had the Fleur cocktail which was the perfect, not too sweet end to the day.

So good that we wound up coming here twice on our 6 day vacation. The oysters (plain/raw and charbroiled) were incredible. They shuck them behind the bar where they're kept on ice. Their drinks are potent and the service is friendly. A comfortable place for a good meal amid the craziness of the French Quarter.
This is our GO TO place for Charbroiled Oysters, and its the only thing that we have actually ordered from here, but they are outstanding! Maybe next time we will actually eat a full meal here.

I was in town for a few days and stopped here on the recommendation of a local. I'm glad I did. My server was friendly and the experience was nice. (Although there was one other server walking around who acted like he was a big shot- telling all the other waiters what to do, that pissed me off). 

Anyway, food= dynamite. I got the Charbroiled Oysters OMG and half a pound of broiled shrimp. 

All in all it was delicious and I would definitely return!

Excellent oysters! Staff was great and very helpful also. 
The Bloody Marys were awesome also!  A must have drink with the oysters and they put pickled green beans, along with a bunch of other "goodness" to garnish the Bloody Mary with. 
We didn't order any other menu items, but the Po' Boy sandwiches looked amazing there too. Next time, that's what I'm going to order.

Went pretty late at about 10pm and according to yelp they close at 1am though they actually closed at 11, so that was disappointing. The food was good and we got a free appetizer due to yelp so that was a plus. The biggest downer was that they close their balcony early so we were unable to each out there. The food was good and thr pricing was decent. It was a good experience but there were a few bumps in the road.

We dined here on a Friday night and the place was packed with a line, so that means they are doing something right. Service was efficient and friendly. 

We ordered one of each from the oyster offerings. Each was good but our favorite was the charbroiled. My only complaints are that the oysters are not nearly as big as at Crecent City, and at Acme they use real cheese instead of grated parm from a container. Still, we enjoyed everything. The raw oysters were tasty, the stuffed oysters were good, and the rockefeller were also good. The bloody mary that the wife started with was one of the best of her life. Maybe THE best. At $10 it better be good. 

If you don't feel like dealing with throngs of tourists (like us) at Acme, this place is a perfectly good alternative to get your oyster fix while in New Orleans. I would return.

feels a bit touristy, but we were tourists anyway. yummy gumbo (both seafood and regular), cheap oysters (a little over $1 per if you get a dozen--pretty standard around these parts, as i gather), clean if small bathrooms.
Stopped for lunch today and loved it.  Oysters and gumbo!!!!

I know I should try the oysters here, but I stopped by for a quick snack and had the French onion soup. The soup was flavorful , rich, and seasoned well. It was a tad too salty, but most of the French onion soup I have tried have been pretty salty. My friend had the crab claws and those were great. Their other dishes also looked solid.

Stopped into Royal House for a quick lunch before heading to the Saints game while on a trip to New Orleans.  It really wasn't planned, just a convenient right time/right place kind of a thing, but I was pleasantly surprised.  They were doing some construction here at the time, but the service was still good, and the food was better than average.  We were sat outside in a patio like area.  It was boxed in by surrounding buildings, which actually made it a nice place to eat.  I will say there were birds sorta flying in and out of the place, but they didn't really bother anyone. 

I tried Gumbo for the first time, and I have to say, I'm a fan.  I definitely plan on working this in to my arsenal more often, especially if it means another trip to New Orleans.  I also had a roast beef Po'Boy which was also really good.  The roast beef was cooked just right, and the Po'Boy is smothered in brown gravy, and lets face it, gravy makes everything good.
Checked in with Yelp and got a free appetizer which we ordered spinach seafood dip (yummy) and dinner was excellent! Service was very friendly!

First off, try the craw fish cakes for an appetizer. They were very good! I had the poy -boy here, I was not that impressed. 
The service was friendly, the outdoor seating was slanted, so you do sit at an angle. Only seats two people outside but we made three fit.

My coworker and I ate here our first night in New Orleans, pretty much just because it was across from our hotel and I was too exhausted to go anywhere else. It far exceeded my expectations.

Our waitress was incredibly nice and personable. She had no idea what Old Bay was when I took a chance and asked if they had any for the corn and crab bisque, but brought out some cajun seasoning that helped the bisque. The bisque was more corn than crab, but it was pretty good.

The fried catfish platter was ridiculously large, like, could've easily fed two people large. The catfish itself was really good. The hush puppies that came with it were also really good, but I wasn't expecting the jalapenos in them and that was sort of an unpleasant, spicy surprise. 

Also had some large fruity drink, can't remember what it was, but it was good and strong.

It is going to be hard to tell you how much I loved this place, because you kinda had to be there. 

My bach party had ballooned to 18 guys. We were at Pat O'Briens and it was about 6pm. We had 830 reservations. I was STARVING, and wanted some local fare. 

I whipped out the Yelp app and put in oysters, and Royal House was tenths of a mile away. I was so happy I may or may not have shed a drop. Me and 4 buddies dipped out for some oysters, promising to meet the rest of the fellas at our rezzy. 

Walked in and they had 5 spots at the bar. Destiny my friends. 

Two gents behind the bar were already shucking oysters. Didn't even need to see a menu. A dozen for me. 

Growing up in Boston, you learn to appreciate fresh seafood. Living in Nashville now, you can get good seafood, but you have to pay a premium for it. And, it's missing that extra element of fresh that you just can't get in a non-port town. That being said, these oysters were so fresh, I was amazed. 

Ended up getting the cooked trio of oysters as well. Highly recommend. 

If you are in the mood for fresh oysters or seafood, go here immediately.

Excellent service and pretty good food for a "tourist area". The French Onion Soup was delicious (a little salty, but still good) and oysters were reasonably priced as well. Overall, I would recommend it based on the location, price, and service.

If you find yourself in the French Quarter looking for a restaurant, find this place!  The atmosphere is warm and friendly and the food is absolutely delicious.  Oh, and the service is as good as it gets.

This is our first visit to NOLA, and this was the first place we had dinner. Our waitress was awesome... very friendly and helpful with the menu items. My hisband and I split the seafood platter, which was more than enough food for the both of us, but a little bit too "fried" for my taste. We would definitely go here again.

This place is a MUST go in the French Quarter. We dropped in for a late dinner and shared:
1) Oysters:  average - I've had better 
2) Crab and Corn Bisque: One of the best soups I ever had - rich, creamy, and flavorful - a perfect balance of fresh crab and corn
3) Sauteed Crab Claws:  AMAZING...The crab meat was tender and the lemon butter sauce was so good I could drink it - it came with 2 slices  of  french bread which was heavenly with the sauce
The waitress was super nice and had a new term of endearment every time she checked in on us: babies, honeys, sweeties =)

Surprisingly, one of the only restaurants open late in the French Quarter! Although we were limited on options for dining, we got very lucky with Royal House. 

After a long day of travel and stressful traffic due to a football game, we were starving and not too happy about being told everything else was closed or closing at about ten thirty at night. 

C'mon, this is New Orleans! You can get a daquiri here anytime of day, but not a decent meal?

Royal House served us quickly and filled our bellies. Our server, Joseph, was attentive without being overbearing. 

I personally recommend the corn and crab chowder and the Bananas Foster cheesecake. Their portions are generous and probably big enough to share if you aren't as ravenous as we were. The desserts are definitely big enough for 3 people to have conservative bites of. Everything was very fresh and the other diners I was with raved about their oysters.

Their prices are fair. 

My biggest turn off is the seating--the tables are more like cafe sized, so four people are knocking elbows with one another. Other than this, the food was good and we left happy and full.

We go to nola every year for jazzfest and try as many new restaurants as possible. We stumbled onto this place super randomly and thought it looked awesome. There was a 45 mintue wait and we were starving after having spent all day at the fairgrounds but the atmosphere just looked too good to pass up. 

It was rocky at first, our 45 min wait turned into a 1:15 wait. I would assume it was a new host they had just kind of thrown in there an he totally skipped over our party. After we spoke with the supervisor she immediately seated us at a great table with possibly the best server ive ever had, and myself and my friends are all in the service industry in San Diego. TIM IS THE MAN. 

Granted this was all the way back in May, but I haven't been able to stop raving about this place and how great he was. A person in our group nailed it when she said "Tim was casually on his sh*t." Anytime it seemed like food our drinks were taking a little too long, Tim would pop by give a smile and give us a surprisingly accurate eta. Drinks were delicious and I don't even like oysters but damn they were good.

We loved this place so much we went back the next day, sat at the same table and asked for Tim. I HIGHLY recommend this place over Acme and if he's still there, sit with Tim if you want an amazing experience.

Really nice to spend a nice quite dinner with your Partner in New Orleans. We went there almost closing time but received great service and food. We were giving a nice table next to the big doors which were partially opened. All the items we ordered were very tasty and unique. The restaurant deserves a second visit.

I just got home from a lovely dinner at Royal House. I decided to bring my future mother-in-law here for dinner, just the 2 of us. The atmosphere was busy and lively, but not too loud. We followed suit and ordered the crab claw appetizer. I do not regret this appetizer one bit! 

For dinner I had the taste of New Orleans (because I like to sample everything!): the gumbo was spicy with a flavorful roux, the jambalaya was flavorful and the rice was cooked to perfection, and the étouffée was delicious (although a little "soupier" than I'm used to). The MIL got the fried shrimp platter and loved it!. Oh and I got the fleur de tini cocktail and it was delicious! I would like to come back and get the chargrilled oysters to see if they are indeed better than Drago's...

This was my second dinner experience at Royal House, and I would definitely take more guests from out of town here. The 2 of us got in right away at 8:30 on a Saturday night and the service was awesome. Go here for date night or an intimate dinner with friends/family. Looked like they easily accommodate large groups (there were several there tonight), but they weren't taking reservations when I called ahead tonight.

Not worth it in my opinion. I don't understand why it has such amazing reviews. Maybe we ordered the wrong thing. Perhaps the staff was just having an off night. I'm willing to accept that but it doesn't change my opinion. The food was lackluster. The wine was terrible. The staff came around semi-often at first but then he pulled the old magic trick and disappeared. Gave it a try, not going back.

What a great experience.  The food was exceptional, not overseasoned with large portions.  The decor is typical NOLA Oyster Bar with a great menu.  We used our Yelp online coupon for some Sauted Crab Claws which were sensational.
Wife had the Schrimp Tortelline which she is still raving about.  I had the Shrimp Creole which was full of shrimp and a very tastely creole sause.

We will be back
Great bloody Marys. Oysters are very fresh. Wait staff very attentive and friendly!
Great food great price and great singer outside at night!

The food and service were both great. We went on New Years Eve and although they were not taking reservations they were accurate on the wait time only 15-20 minutes.  Our server was very friendly. The french onion soup was amazing. I am not a seafood fan so I paired that with the blackened chicken sandwich, which was a blackened chicken sandwich. My husband had the charbroiled oysters and said they were great. I would hit this place again on my next trip to New Orleans.
Way too pricey for what it is! I was drunk when we went inside. Sorry Honey but even more, sorry Walet.

Went here on my resent visit to New Orleans for dinner. Located in the french quarter you can expect high prices but a nice old time atmosphere when dinning here. We got here relatively early so we were seated right away. Glad we came early because this place was packed on our way out. They don't except reservations either so best advice is to arrive early. We were also lucky to be seated upstairs. I'm sure our experience would have been totally different on the first floor. The people seated close to the door were all wearing there winter jackets because they got nailed with the cold breeze every time the door opened (it was 35 degrees out).  The 1st level was also very crowded and cramped. My advice if you go here is to ask to be seated upstairs. Our waiter was very friendly and knew the menu well. If I was rating on service I would give them 5 stars. For dinner I ordered the burger. It was good but nothing special. My dad had the Po-boy sandwich and also agreed that it was good but not worth the money. When our bill came I was surprised they actually added in the gratuity. We only had a party of five and I find this practice insulting. Royal house gets two stars because of the cramped 1st floor dinning room (glad we didn't get seated there) and over priced just ok food.

My boyfriend and I walked into the Royal House while looking for a breakfast or brunch place while in the French Quarter. Unfortunately, it did not really have breakfast but they looked like they had pretty good oysters. My boyfriend had not had the opportunity this trip to get oysters yet so we decided to give it a try. 

First off, the service. The service was fantastic. The host made a point of talking to us, asked how many, sat us at our table, etc. The usual. However, he also let us know where the bathrooms were, the bar, who our server would be and really made us feel at home and comfortable. It was something that was easy but quickly set the Royal House apart. Our server was named Robert. He was also really nice. Originally we were planning on using a "check-in deal" from Yelp that allowed a free appetizer with a purchase. However, Robert informed us you had to buy two entrees that cost a specific amount and since we were just looking for something light we decided to skip the deal and give it a try anyways. In the middle of the meal a parade went down Royal Street for the Sugar Bowl. We were trying to peer out the windows to see and Robert made a point of coming over and telling us to just head outside and check out the parade, and "no one will bother our food." After the parade, one of the employees walked around delivering beads to ALL of the customers that he had collected during the parade. Service was definitely a 5 star. 

The food (and drinks). We started with a Bloody Mary each. They infused vodka in house which we were really excited to try. The drinks were good, but they were a little thin at the end and being in New Orleans for a few days I was hoping for a great Bloody Mary where you could taste the seasonings the whole time and never thinned out from ice. The food was good. Ben liked his oysters a lot and thought they were really fresh. We split some spinach dip and an order of hush puppies. Both were good, but unfortunately none of the food was amazing. 

I would definitely return for the service!

I've visited NOLA only twice, but I've hit Royal House four, maybe five times. It's definitely the place to be if you can snag a table looking out a window, so you can do your people watching on Royal Street while enjoying a few beers and a dozen or two oysters. And yes, on one of my trips, I did exactly that.

On our first night in NOLA, my husband and I enjoyed a casual dinner upstairs at Royal House. It was the perfect introduction to NOLA cuisine. 

Husband got the trio sampler - gumbo, jambalaya, and etouffee. Delicious! The portions were also very generous - all in three soup cups. He also enjoyed a margarita that was tasty. 

I got the pound of shrimp boil with potatoes and corn. The shrimp had a mighty spice, and the corn was delicious. The potatoes are unseasoned and just boiled, so make sure you lather it in the shrimp sauce, but only if you like spicy! Husband accidentally licked his fingers and found himself drinking his water long after. 

Service was kind and helpful. Royal House is located really conveniently on Royal by some really lovely buildings.

We were a party of two; the host was very nice and sat us at a good table, but then it all went downhill. The waiter was negligent at best, he disappeared and he did not bring us water until we asked for it at the end of the night. The food took a long time to be served; we had to ask the waiter about our order and all he could say was "the kitchen is backed up." When the food came, the crab cakes were cold; the rest of the food was fine. For dessert we ordered coffee and bread pudding, and, oh surprise, there was a BUG in my partner's coffee cup, which she had to spit out in disgust. A very disappointing first meal in New Orleans.

Ate here for Christmas Dinner. Was told the wait would be 30 min but ended up being only 15. We were there for the Revillion Dinner. You need to ask for a special menu. The food was excellent and was a great value. The ambience for Christmas and the traditional Revillion Dinner was lacking since they continued to serve their regular menu along with the other dinners being very casual.

The shrimp po boy had hardly any shrimp or fixings inside. There wasn't even sauce on top. C'mon, a dry Po Boy?! Served on dry stale bread. 

The 2 stars is more for the service, which was good and the drinks were ok. Pricey though. 3 cocktails, 1 beer and 1 sandwich  and gratuity was $60. Not worth the hype!!
Delicious, classy, great service, well-priced...what more could you want. I had the blackened Cajun Redfish. Really good and really a nice place to have dinner in "The Quarter".

My girlfriend and I were looking to eat dinner at around 5 on NYE and we had a reservation at another restaurant. After surveying the restaurant (and the menu at the restaurant) we quickly opened Yelp and found this gem. We walked up to the front door shortly after five and we were seated immediately.

Our waiter (Dominic) was great. He was genuinely enthusiastic about the food at the restaurant and also taking care of us. The seafood gumbo was outstanding and my girlfriend had the Shrimp Creole which was outstanding. We really lucked out finding this gem at such a busy time & I am so glad we decided to change our dinner plans.

A friend and I were looking for a place where we could get good traditional new orleans food. And I think this place does the trick. It's not too much of a tourist place. There menu has all the best traditional nola foods. Service was fast. In fact they were completely full when we went but still managed to seat us. They have nice seats next to shutter like windows that overlook the streets like a lot of downtown NOLA restaurants.

At the junction of St. Louis and Royal Sts. this oyster bar is in the heart of the French Quarter. We were here late night and sat at the counter even though tables and chairs were available. Closing time, which I now can see online is listed as 1am, must have been imminent. The bar tender understandably was cleaning and wiping things down while we ate, but in general his attitude seemed tired and ready to go home (probably also understandable, but just saying). Nevertheless, the raw oysters were good and came from the kitchen quickly. I'd label this oyster eating experience as equal to other places I have had them in NOLA such as French Market Restaurant & Bar, but above other places such as Felix's.

We came here for the last dinner of our NOLA trip and had a great experience. Despite the fact that the first mardi gras parade had just wrapped up, we were seated in 10 minutes. The host kept apologizing for the wait and it seemed like he was genuinely sorry we had to wait so long, despite the fact that they'd gotten us in earlier than predicted. We were seated by a window so we could enjoy all the activity on the street as the parade wound down. Our waiter was Charles and he made us feel really welcome, so the whole experience was a lot of fun.

We started with a dozen oysters and the stuffed mushrooms. At home, $1/oyster is a happy hour price; in NOLA, $1/oyster is tourist prices, for much bigger, juicier, and more delicious oysters. I could not get enough of those Louisiana Bay beauties, they were so wonderful. The mushrooms were stuffed with this light but totally packed crab stuffing, which my boyfriend absolutely loved. 

Next, we ordered the Taste of New Orleans (jambalaya, crawfish etouffee, and seafood gumbo; all wonderful) and some fried alligator. I'd had gator before, but none this good. Royal House taught me that alligators are both fashionable and delicious! Overall, totally great meal and service experience. I would definitely come back next time I'm in NOLA!

Royal House's second floor balcony seating was indeed royal treatment: it was awesome because of the amazing view.

We got three dishes in total: the cooked oyster duo was the HIT! Duo is comprised of the "Rockerfeller style" (cheeeeese) and "Royal House style" (the best!)

The seafood gumbo was just ok.
The shrimp platter was awful, both shrimps and fries were way too much fried, and the coleslaw was disgusting overfilled with sauce.

So, my recommendation at the end of the day would be get the Oyster and enjoy your Margarita on the second floor balcony. Then that would be what I call "perfection". :)

On New Year's Eve, my group of friends and I (who were in town for the Sugar Bowl) headed out late.  We had spent the day on the road, so by the time we checked into our hotel, got ready for the big night, and headed out, we were pretty hungry.  Or at least I was.  We had no specifics in mind, but we anticipated a long wait.  Upon seeing Royal House, we went in and found out the wait was fairly short.  We laughed with the host and were seated quickly.

We ordered drinks, which were delicious.  Alligator bites were next, and they set the tone for our eating in New Orleans!  As in... they were awesome!  We each ordered different things for our meals.  I'm not even much on seafood, but I had decided I was having a shrimp po' boy on this trip...  so why not at Royal House?  It was on point!!!  It did have a LOT of bread with it, and since I was somewhat watching what I was eating, I didn't even touch it.  However, the shrimp and everything else was delicious.

Everyone enjoyed their meals, and we had good service.  I wish I could remember the name of our server--he was fun.  This was a great way to kick off our time New Orleans; we enjoyed our dinner here.  I would be glad to go back next time I visit!
Great Charbroiled Oysters! I'm officially a fan. Service was 5 star too.

Food was unbelievable. They have Oyster beignets which I thought was rather unique at first glance on the menu. When I was presented with them, it turned into  rather heavenly experience. Entrees were great as well. 

As far as service.... They were understaffed, but the server was good and the manager did well to check on tables.

Quick service during Mardi Gras. Had a spicy Bloody Mary to start with the fried alligator appetizer. Got the taste of New Orleans platter which had crab, gumbo, and jambalaya ..all pretty good. Still looking for a bowl of gumbo with crab legs. My friend got the red fish which was delicious and blackened with green beans. Great meal for 2 for about $80.

With 200 + reviews, I'm not sure what to add, but I had a terrific meal here and wanted to add my two cents to the mix. We did not have any mains, but the four of us trolled thru the starters, and leaned on anything with the word oyster in it. The chargrlled were some of the best in NOLA, and the Oyster Duo was also excellent. The outstanding do not miss is the sauteed crab claws-really, really special (ask for extra toasted  bread-trust me)The only one I'd pass on in the future was the oyster beignets on a stick, I thought them too sweet to mix with the seafood.

The service was excellent and the place very well kept.

Oysters! This place was surprisingly good. I thought it would be really overpriced and touristy considering its location. It was filled with tourists, but some locals too eating at the bar. Prices were on par with other quarter restaurants. Oysters were great! Both raw and charbroiled. My friend got a fried shrimp platter and shrimp were huge and plentiful. Overall I would recommend this to visitors to the city looking for a good place to eat in the quarter or anyone looking for an oyster bar in the quarter!

Our first night going out as a group, and we chose Royal House.  I've walked by this place in the past and they never seem to have a wait.  Well, now I understand why...   Our server was the friendliest woman we had ever met but she was so slow to take our orders and our food arrived cold and she got all the orders wrong.   Everyone got some sort of bourbon or beer, so you can't go wrong with that, but I ordered a mint julep, and that was a mistake.  It arrived in a tall pilsner glass and I could not taste any liquor, let alone the mint!   This drink was pure sugar..should have been called the sugar julep!    Well, all four of us ordered the Shrimp Po-Boy, and I think they split their one batch of shrimp between 4 people.  These po'boys were (1) cold (2) incorrectly dressed (3) lacking in freshness, the bread was SO hard.   We substituted fries for 'red beans and rice, WHOA, big mistake, this was definitely not the best or even good red beans and rice.   

Needless to say, after waiting so long for our check, we took our group and went out on a search to find better po'boys!

This place has grown on me - in a good way. Though my first experience at Royal House was not great, it was probably my fault; being new to New Orleans at the time. Now, I really LOVE this place. The food is good and fresh and the service staff is great. They remember names and faces and great you with a smile.

My personal favorite is the oysters: raw, of course but the char-grilled oysters are a very close second. They're always fresh and clean. I highly recommend you stop in for a dozen anytime you're near.
Wish I could say different, but wasn't impressed at all. Over-priced oysters and they were the size of nickles. Probably won't be coming back
Try the seafood gumbo and hush puppies! No sweet tea, but the location, food, and staff can't be beat!

Overpriced for what you get.  I had shrimp and grits and the grits were bland and not very cheesy for Gouda grits.  My husband got the lobster ravioli and the portion was pretty small but it was tasty.  The crab law appetizer was the highlight of the meal, sautéed and perfectly cooked.  They need to give twice the amount of French bread
With it though, the lemon butter is so good you will want to clean the plate!

We went here on a Saturday afternoon. We had been here many times and always loved the food. This Saturday they weren't very busy and we were seated upstairs. It took forever for the server to come to the table. We actually had to ask for one to be sent to us. He came over and apologized and took our drink and food orders. We then sat there for 35 minutes and we had only ordered appetizers. When they arrived everything was cold. We tried to get someone to come over to the table without success. My boyfriend then had to get up and find the manager. He found her and she came over and apologized said the she would take care of it. We got another order and told we wouldn't be charged, but we were. However the Oysters Royale were amazing. Since it was so good food wise we decided to stop back for dinner later the same night. This time there was a half hour wait. But then the host recognized us from the afternoon and sat us right away. Service This time was excellent. The food was awesome and desert (Bananas foster cheese cake)  was great to. The host really made us feel appreciated and is one of the reasons we return every time we are in town.

This review is solely for the bar area & the oyster shucking station...
Stopped in shortly before midnight on 2/23/13 cause I wanted a dozen and an Abita!! This spot delivered in spades...I didn't get the shuckers name but he basically was also my bartender...pulled me a quick Abita Amber draft and was lightning on my dozen...them oysters were fresh, plump and juicy...also they were that perfect medium size...just right for slurping off the shell!!

Matter of fact they were so damn good I did another 1/2 dozen...the shucker was reading my mind and when he saw how fast that dozen was going down he knew I was gonna want some more so when I was about 9 in we kinda had this telepathic moment and just made eye contact...no words exchanged and BAM! there was another 1/2 dozen of them perfectly sized bi-valves!!

Scoping out the menu and the rest of the place while waiting on my 1st dozen has got me putting this place on my "gotta get a meal here" list...I liked the looks of the place and the menu offerings and will try a full sit down meal in the not too distant future...if the service and food is as good as what I got at the bar then I'll have another go-to eats option in the Quarter!

While I don't think our experience is exactly indicative of the entire Royal House experience, I have to say that we were happy with our visit. After walking around all day, we were ready to sit, and wanted a drink. We passed Royal House, noticed that there were tables open on the balcony and our decision was made. 

The host who helped us upstairs was great. Our interaction lasted maybe 45 seconds, but he had me laughing as he went through his whole spiel of the only rule being that we can have whatever we want as he let us pick out our table. Very nice guy, and he set the tone for great service. This was continued through our server, who took great care of us even though our ticket price was probably a bit lower than people having a full meal. Great customer service, all the way.

Now for food, we did get a bit to much on. We had a dozen oysters and fried alligator bites. Both were tasty. The portion size for the gator was tiny, but I think that's to be expected. The oysters were quite large and delicious! I cannot recall the price any more, but it was definitely reasonable. A bottle of champagne rounded things out, which I think cost somewhere in the high $30s, again reasonable.

I think what made this experience stand out for me was the great people watching of the balcony. We had front row seats to not only a magician but also a really great bluegrass band. I don't get a lot of street performance back home, so I definitely get a kick out of it when traveling to places like New Orleans. And personally, I think the best view to watch the French Quarter shenanigans is from above.

I wouldn't say that Royal House was a fantastic culinary adventure or a "best kept secret" type of establishment, but it fit our needs perfectly and left us with some good vacation memories. I approve.

Really great oyster place in NOLA! 

Appetizer- crawfish cakes. Absolutely fantastic! The sauce was amazing

Dinner- I tried the combination platter- Rockefeller and Royale! Pretty good! Not the best I've ever had, but I definitely enjoyed it.

We also got the shrimp creole, and it was probably the best creole I've ever had!! Definitely recommend trying that!

Great service and strong drinks!
The crawfish raviolis were pretty good, a nice size portion. The raviolis were plump with a good amount of filling and it had a flavorful orange cream.
Oysters were on POINT! Didn't give 5 stars b/c the Blood Mary wasn't the best... decent though.

Awesome oysters. Great bloody Marys.  It was very much worth getting off Bourbon street to eat here.  Excellent service as well.   Everything we had was top notch.  Ask teh waiter for their preferences....that is what we did.

Anticipating leaving the next day, we ventured back to the FQ for our last dinner in LA.  I chose Royal House because of it's pretty good review on Yelp and the food was, in fact, pretty good!  We were seated near the windows which made for great weekend people watching and our server was friendly, upbeat and more than happy to assist what was probably her millionth tourist of the night.  With my Yelp checkin I received a free appetizer of up to $10 which really covered only one appetizer, spinach dip.  That's right, spinach dip at a seafood restaurant.  No thanks!  We inquired about the other apps on the menu and she stated that we could cover any amount over the $10 limit, which we agreed to do and ordered the crab claws.  Because we were splitting the bill (thanks to the corporate credit card) the amount would be charged to my card but half of the discount would go to me and half would go to my mom.  Weird.  The claw tips were good, small, and served in a delicious "calorie conscious" lemon garlic butter sauce with toasted french bread for dipping.  The french bread wasn't exactly fresh, and the claws were exactly meaty, but it was good for a free app.  For dinner I ordered the jambalaya with grilled shrimp and my mom ordered the shrimp po boy.  The shrimp were large and cooked perfectly while the jambalaya was flavorful but lacking the spice I had hoped for.  My mom said her po boy was delicious and more flavorful than others she had while in town.  Although our server was great about refills in the beginning, she totally disappeared towards the end of the meal.  It seemed like we waited at least 20 minutes after we finished eating to get our bill, and then quite some time after we set out our cards to complete the transaction.  It wasn't overly busy so I couldn't really figure out what the holdup was!  Overall it was a good meal in a historic building with a nice view of the oyster bar.  It's also close enough to bourbon street to see all the craziness, but not close enough to get annoyed by the debauchery!

Best place we ate the entire time in  NOLA. Well worth the 40 min. wait. Fried oyster platter, stuffed mushroom appetizer, crawfish ravioli, some NOLA platter (hubby got it but I can't remember name), and Rum bread pudding all fantastic. I want the recipes for the hush puppies and coleslaw!  We will definitely go back next time we are in NO.

drinks=5 stars
service= 5 stars
food= 3 stars

Came here on a Sunday night with the hubby. It was a short wait. The bar was packed, but the drinks were very good. I don't remember what my fav drink was called but it had vodka and champagne. 
The service was good. Everyone was friendly and checked on us frequently. 
The food was not worth the price, in my opinion. The oysters weren't as good as other places, and they were more expensive. My tortellini was okay. I had higher expectations for the place and the price. I will go back again, but I'll stick to the drinks only.

I did not have the best experience here with the food, but the waitstaff was very friendly and attentive.  Ugh, just thinking about the food experience.  I'll save some of the details but there was a non food item in my shrimp n grits and the oysters tasted like saltwater when they should have been chargrilled. 'twas not a good experience.

3.5 stars

Food was good, nothing outstanding. Oysters were delicious and fresh, gumbo was decent, had a salad with grilled scallops. Scallops were a little too small for my liking and lacking a bit of flavor, but overall meal was good.
Relaxed atmosphere, quick service, great price on oysters

We had friends recommend that we go to the Royal House on a recent trip to NOLA. It was our first destination for lunch on day 1. We told our waiter Chris that we wanted to share several dishes. He suggested the best oysters we had ever had! We followed that with a salad and a po boy. The food was just what we wanted. I had to have a hurricane of course too.  Chris was so great that we came back everyday on our trip to sit at the bar and have oysters and drinks. I can't wait to go back!!

Royal House wasn't as authentic as I had hoped. 

I'll have to start with the cons:
We ordered the Oysters Trio which were a little dry. The remoulade was not my favorite.  The Jambalaya tasted like generic rice pilaf. Sadly, the Gumbo had a rubbing alcohol taste to it. 

But...for the pros:
The Crawfish Etouffée was the best item on there. And surprisingly, the Linguine and Clams were tasty -- not that New Orleans is known for their Linguine and Clams. The  Bread Pudding with ice cream was yummy and rich. And I will say we got great service. Our server was on top of it with the iced tea refills.

Maybe the pluses and minuses evened the experience out for a three-star rating, but I will likely take my money elsewhere for the quality and value.

Came here with my partner for a late lunch, and one of the best meals of my life! We were seated immediately and our server was attentive and helpful. They also honor the Yelp check in for a free appetizer, which is nice!

We had crab claws in butter and lemon sauce, oysters on the half shell, and the crawfish etouffée. The crab claws were our appetizer (suggested by our serves), and the SAUCE. OH MY GOD THE SAUCE. Seriously, hands down, amazing sauce. The oysters were delicious and brine-y. I liked my crawfish etouffée, but I legit kept going back to the crab claws sauce. 

So good. Definitely a great lunch spot.
Great place...Tasty shrimp and deep Creole flavored in the Jambalaya!

Only having a couple of days in Nawlins we wanted to go somewhere w/ local seafood and fish while not too expensive and serving good drinks. the royal house was a great choice for us. and the service was really outstanding, our waiter was great. 

the fresh oysters here are among the best i have ever had. i could have eaten those oysters all night and if you're going, get those oysters. the rest of our dinners were amazing too-the crawfish etouffee, seafood tortellini and bread pudding were all hits. the drinks we had from the bar were also great, we had hurricanes and bloody mary's and both tasted fantastic. 

if i find myself in Nawlins again i would definitely go back.

This was the first place we stopped at to dine in NOLA. 
What stood out to me the most about this place was the very kind waitress who offered to SPLIT our bill for our party of 11.  I've never experienced such a kind offer since many establishments in the Bay Area frown upon this request.  
Now onto the food, some of the notable dishes were:
1. Taste of New Orleans: Just like the title says, you get to taste Jambalaya, Crawfish etouffee, and Chicken and Sausage Gumbo- which were all delish
2. Fried Alligator: We were super excited to try this and ordered a round for the whole table.  The alligator meat reminded us of chicken, but a bit chewier.  This is something you must try if ever in NOLA
3. Oyster Beignets: While these were good, it wasn't what we were expecting.  They're mainly just fried oysters with some sweet (asian flavored to me) sauce glazed over it.
Menu was okay, nothing special or extremely delicious. The service was awful and the food was a little overpriced. This place is just ok, nothing special and nothing to go out of your way for.

We had been here for 5 day before we picked the  Royal House and sampled lots of other restaurants.  The reviews looked good, so off we went.  There were 5 of us, and when we arrived we were told  about 20 min. wait, which isn't to back for the Quarter.  After waiting, they escorted us to a large  room up stairs that only had people at one table.  

Things were slow, but that was OK.  First waring, if you check their menu on line, the items are close but the price is up $2-$3.  Four of our dinners arrived and the fifth was at least 10 minutes later.  I have to admit my Pescatore was very good, spicy and lots of sea food.  My wife ordered a Royal salad, it came with old lettuce and the oysters so overcooked you could have used them as golf balls.  They charge extra for refills on diet and ice tea, and then they are only 1/2 full, in the end we were charged $12 diet. 

There are a lot better choices in the quarter for restaurants, so go someplace different.  I would not recommend this place to anyone.
